title: Building a dashboard for a water treatment plant
body:
## Intro

CABB stands for Consorcio de Aguas Bilbao Bizkaya. Theyâ€™re the ones in charge of providing Bilbao with clean water, as well as purifying the wastewater created.

As a product designer for DigitaLinkers, my task was to re-design their SCADA system (A SCADA is a central controller for industrial machinery).

![Homepage before the project started](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/QPKgmNucsRGYbh0rVoVbi.png?height=742&width=1440&size=medium)

\**This particular software is only available for Desktop, and they have a fixed resolution for their screens, which made responsive irrelevant for this project.*

## Discovery

In the discovery phase of the process, we identified 2 main users who would interact with the system on a constant basis: Management and operations. We run a Design thinking workshop where we went deep in this topic and identified areas to work on, as well as defined both usersâ€™ interests.

![Pictures from the design thinking workshop](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4g1cL0TbsrdX8nfMA84z5.png?height=708&width=1160&size=medium)

## Users

### Management

Interested in the overall functioning of the plant. They want to know everything is working fine, and if thereâ€™s something they should be aware of.

### Operations

Interested in their area. If thereâ€™s an issue and theyâ€™re responsible for it, they have to be aware of whatâ€™s going on, and take actions on it.

## Areas to work on

### Usability

One of the biggest pain points they had is that the initial page was unable to understand if you had no experience with it. The main driver for this project was to have a system that was more usable by all of the profiles involved.

### Accessibility

The SCADA is used 24/7 in different kind of screens (from 23â€ to 60â€ screens) and in different environments, so sometimes it was very tiring to look at.

## Constrains

As this is a 3rd party software where integrators were doing their magic on top of it, it came with a couple limitations and design constrains that we had to work with.

1. There were limitations in terms of charts and information we could display
2. There was a pre-defined way of showing errors that would be followed

As this was my first (and only so far) SCADA project, we had a very close relationship with the developers, where I needed their guidance on the Doâ€™s and Donâ€™ts for the project.

## Hands on

### UI

One of the first decisions we made was to reduce all the color weight the interface had to make it more readable. Also, we went through a process where we defined the data and tried to put it all together in one screen.

### Data definition

During the workshop we created a doc where we wrote down the data each of the profiles needed to be displayed in the initial dashboard.

Afterwards, we went through a definition process to discover which data was really important, what we could get rid of, and what was missing.

This was a weekly iterative process, where I showed my progress on Friday, we went over it, discussed it and got some initial feedback, and then they sent all the final feedback on Tuesday. Then Iâ€™d present my progress on Friday, and so on.

![Data definition iterations](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/nb-D4rMrZWSCszOutBkjY.png?height=700&width=3096&size=medium)

### Data visualization

Once data was somewhat defined (there were still some unknowns, but we were confident we could finish this as the process advanced), we moved on to a DataViz phase. We used the same iteration model, where we were validating weekly our decisions.

![DataViz iterations](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wxNftUn_Kml_XQDukWIwL.png?height=1080&width=5792&size=medium)

## Final result

![Final Dashboard design](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HS1m3rKKN4ysvLULtPDhc.png?height=1080&width=1920&size=medium)

In the end, the client was happy with it, and the initial feedback I got from it was very positive, so you could say the final result was a good one.

Sadly, when you work for an agency most of the times you donâ€™t follow the project after you deliver it, so I donâ€™t have actual data to see how the system is performing and what should be improved - thereâ€™s always something to be improved.

![Before & after](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/NB9vjL_GzuZdDL2sX9ZBL.png?height=742&width=2776&size=medium)

Nevertheless, from the agency they still say the client is satisfied, so I take that as a win ğŸ™‚

title: What I learned the past two weeks...
body:
What do you value today? 

Family, relationships, A cat named Jim. Maybe itâ€™s not people/ pets though. Maybe itâ€™s freedom, independence, or worldly experiences. Maybe itâ€™s your health and wellness. Maybe itâ€™s Power, Fame, Success. My point being, we place value on a number of different things in our life today.

What does the â€œworldâ€ value today?

A hybrid of the things above potentially, but also the value of the USD.

There is a colloquial saying, â€œCash is King,â€ meaning cash is more valuable than any other form of investment tools. Whether you agree with this sentiment or not, how did â€œcashâ€ become so valuable?

[https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cash-is-king.asp](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cash-is-king.asp)

Well Iâ€™ll give you a pencil and napkin summary here.

First it started during the Hunter Age, when people traded crops and cattle. Then, people started going to war and wealth got a bad rep. The Warrior Age created value for the king and if you survived, receiving land was most valuable. People then began forming modern day cities. Useful and decorative crafts became valuable. As cities started to change the landscape, the idea to explore far away lands became a thing so exotic goods became valuable. Craftsmen kept perfecting their skills at home and afar and the introduction of machinery allowed for things to be mass produced so value was created significantly faster. Around this same time, transportation and the demand for fuel was growing. Insert Rockefellerâ€™s and Gettyâ€™s of the world. Now fast forward to the Corporate Age, with transportation demands solved, distributions of factory goods was possible to/from anywhere. Corporations formed from factories with growing departments. With the corporations growing, Banks realized they could buy corporations and resell them. Insert the evolution Fed and corporations now creating value in the order of billions of USD. With corporations employing hundreds of people, people spending money, and banks managing transactionsâ€¦ a significant amount of data was accumulating. Hence the rapid development of technology to manage and organize this data. As technology has evolved, the importance of the security and integrity of this data has caused us to re-evaluate how this data is managed through the evolution of blockchain technology. Now we see are starting to see what we value physically, digitally. 

[https://blog.adioma.com/the-history-of-creating-value-infographic/](https://blog.adioma.com/the-history-of-creating-value-infographic/)

The value of the Euro is predicted to reach $.97 USD by September WSJ reported this morning. Tiktok influencers are flocking to Europe to grab hold of their Gucci, Prada, Coco and Chanel bags for almost half the price they are in the states. Meanwhile Iâ€™m back here wondering if I should get a pet chicken with the cost of eggs rising. All comments aside though, I do wonder how the changing value of the US dollar will impact our future and particularly cryptocurrency?

[https://www.wsj.com/articles/strong-dollar-extends-gains-with-no-end-to-rally-in-sight-11658066581](https://www.wsj.com/articles/strong-dollar-extends-gains-with-no-end-to-rally-in-sight-11658066581)

(Additionally, WSJ reported the WSJ Dollar Index, the index that measures the dollar against a basket of 16 currencies, hit a 20 year high last week and is nearly up 2.5% this month. They also reported the Fed was likely to raise rates by another .75 percentage points this month and are doing what they can to stop rising consumer prices.)

On the future value of currency and its impact on cryptocurrencyâ€¦ some economic theories at play as depicted in Banklessâ€™ interview with Lyn Alden.

[http://podcast.banklesshq.com/127-is-this-the-end-lyn-alden](http://podcast.banklesshq.com/127-is-this-the-end-lyn-alden)

1\. Long Term Debt Cycles: These macroeconomic trends resurface every several decades and each cycle is slightly different but the climax is consistently triggered by massive debt, threadbare interest rates, and currency devaluation. These factors combine to destabilize global systems, meaning ends of eras on a global scale: failing empires, wars, currency rebases, major demographic shifts. Decelerating growth, runway inflation, deep downtrendsâ€¦ when they hit the employment marketâ€¦. its already a recession. Dalio predicts our next recession to be a catalyst for a transition from US-based dominance of the global economy to a multi polar world. Russia, China, Indiaâ€¦ theyâ€™ve already begun detaching from the dollar dominance in the midst of their own financial crises.

2\. Opposing Milkshake Theory: The idea that the global financial upheaval upon which we seem to be flirting will actually be good news for dollar strength as the American economy will ultimately drink everyone elseâ€™s milkshake and re-assert global dominance. Many think this is only true until its not and some predict that short term dollar strength may actually be an indicator of long-term dollar decline. This is because the US Dollar is a global reserve currency. Itâ€™s the currency that most offshore debt is denominated in all over the world and $13 trillion in US denominated debt exist globally and over 50 trillion in US financial assets. With disruption in global cash flows, there is a short squeeze of the dollar and so it spikes upwards. Not really a strength but rather an unfolding weakness of other currencies. Ultimately this leads to an acceleration of the mega-macro move to multi-polarity which diminishes the global reliance on US economy and its dollar. Many signs pointing to this being only months away.

3\. The Fed: Move Slow and Break Stuff: The Fed has been slow to respond to inflation, so now its stuck to move overly aggressively to catch up as economic activity is decelerating. Until the Fed breaks treasuries and credit markets, they will continue to raise rates. It is unlikely they can continue to raise rates until 2023, but they will not stop until it breaks the system. TBD.

How does this impact the crypto market: Interest rate hikes will likely be bad for the crypto market in the short term and right now digital assets are getting hit hard until this all plays out. The Merge is a secret weapon for Ethereum, but crypto as an asset is not really driving the macro environment. The Fed really has much bigger fish to fry right now. Of note the CeFi contagion took out scores of notable crypto banks to the tune of hundred of billions of dollars in just a number of weeks. Crypto is just a precursor to what weâ€™ll see in its legacy equivalent. Infrastructure of crypto, web3, and DeFi have survived one deleveraging stress test but we shall see if they can continue with flying colors.

Axios Crypto reported that Stablecoins are the current focus of regulatory efforts. Bitcoin, which started as a peer-to-peer cash system has worked thus far because retail can't know what it will be worth from day to day. So far stablecoins havenâ€™t disrupted shit. (currently 154B) Without regulation, a stablecoin that enters the mainstream of the financial system and is widely used as a means of payments and/or store of value in multiple jurisdictions could pose significant risks to financial stability. Hence, why no stablecoins are even close to mainstream. However, credit card companies are getting ready now for the possibility as reflected in a recent WSJ article.Â However, the article fails to mention exactly how credit card companies are implementing crypto and also companies that are facilitating crypto for card payments already.

[https://www.wsj.com/articles/cryptocurrency-is-coming-to-your-credit-cards-11657374215](https://www.wsj.com/articles/cryptocurrency-is-coming-to-your-credit-cards-11657374215)

Celsius, a blockchain technology that allowed its customers to earn interest on their cryptocurrency deposits, officially declared Chapter 11 bankruptcy. They will remain in business, but now take time to pay off their debts. How they are branding itâ€¦ â€œopportunity to stabilize their business and consummate a comprehensive restructuring transaction that maximize value for stakeholders.â€

Bad news: There is no clear timeline for when its 300K active users with >$100USD in balances will be able to make withdrawals.

I would expect some layoffs @ Celsius and on top of that Celsius faces a lawsuit against its former investment manager accusing them of being a â€œPonzi Scheme.â€

A calendar hold forâ€¦ September 19th. The new anticipated date of the the Merge, which I discussed in previous writings and referred to above.

[https://cointelegraph.com/news/ethereum-dev-confirms-perpetual-date-for-pos-merge](https://cointelegraph.com/news/ethereum-dev-confirms-perpetual-date-for-pos-merge)

To bring this all togetherâ€¦ last week I took the Enneagram test, which is a personality trait test that is categorized into nine different types. My dominate type was the â€œEnthusiastâ€ or Type 7. Based on this type, I spend a significant amount of time and am strongly influenced in my behaviors and decision-making by what is called the â€œHead Centerâ€ of Intelligence. In short, I think a lot about the question, â€œHow do I navigate the future?â€ This fear based type pays a lot of attention to whatâ€™s going to happen in the future and who/what I can trust to provide guidance through it. This type often struggles with anxiety- trying to outsmart it, outrun it, or allowing it to determine my decisions. 

What we valueâ€¦ past, present, and future, is consistently evolving. While it is important to being thinking about these thingsâ€¦ the future, the state of currency, what is valuableâ€¦ we canâ€™t forget to take a step back and just be present. 

Will leave you with an interesting find in the NFT space below. 

Utilityâ€¦ overused terms these days in my mind. But nonetheless there are a number of use cases being deployed right within the NFT space and sharing an interesting one.

Revulution NFTs

What are they? They are actual certificates of subscription ownership in the form of NFTs. You can now transfer your subscriptions to another person. You can send them as a gift or resell it on the market. If, for some reason you donâ€™t want to use the subscription for a certain period of time, you can rent the NFT and earn a passive income or use it as a collateral for a loan with the launch of protocols on the Cardano network.

Heres the breakdown? You buy the Netflix for life NFT, you pay $349 USD. Then you decide to use it over the next 5 years. The cost of Netflix is $10/month, $120/year, over the course of those five years you save $600 bucks and your Netflix NFT will not use value if you use the subscription.

Whereâ€™s the catch? Only UK and EU citizen can use them (excluding Malta, Germany, and Austria). Subscriptions include Netflix + Spotify

Till next timeâ€¦ keep on keepin it real.

title: Evolutionary Organizations
body:
**Being wrong often is the only way to be right â€“ especially when youâ€™re dealing with complex systems.** This â€“ in a nutshell â€“ is the evolutionary organization thesis. Premature optimization is a sin when it comes to building software and itâ€™s the best way to stunt learning and growth in DAOs. # The Risks of Premature Optimization Premature optimization isnâ€™t just expensive up-front, itâ€™s also costly in the long run. When you design systems that try to anticipate how complex organizations will act, you make a set of assumptions. Some of those assumptions will be correct, and some will be wrong. Ultimately, itâ€™s the **constant testing of those assumptions that allow systems to evolve into sophisticated, well-oiled machines.** And so, when you prematurely optimize DAOs, you end up with a system thatâ€™s often anticipating the wrong problems and thus creating complicated solutions to address problems the DAO does not yet have. This anticipation and problem-solving introduces new sets of assumptions into a system. When you introduce more assumptions, it becomes increasingly difficult to pinpoint why a system is failing â€“ is it because of assumption A or assumption B? The more assumptions you have, the harder it is to figure out which assumptions are wrong and which are right. So why do we prematurely optimize? Fear of failure. We think if we anticipate problems now, we can design our way out of those challenges. But often the opposite is true. In fact, it is this fear of failure that costs time and money in the long-run, as we lose the data and learnings that come from constantly testing assumptions (learning which assumptions are wrong and which are right). # The Evolutionary Organization The key to building complex systems is not designing complexity from the start. Instead, itâ€™s about building simple systems, allowing them to fail, and iterating on those systems based on what works and what does not work. This is [Gallâ€™s Law](http://principles-wiki.net/principles:gall_s_law) in action. One important note: in these systems, failure isnâ€™t just inevitable â€“ itâ€™s actually helpful. By constantly testing assumptions and maximizing learning, **these systems become evolutionary organizations.** # Flexibility But evolutionary organizations donâ€™t just optimize for learning â€“ they also optimize for flexibility. Flexible systems allow organizations to leverage learnings and make incremental improvements (constantly testing assumptions!). When it comes to DAOs (and anything on-chain for that matter), flexibility is rarely designed into systems. But it really should be. Modularity is the name of the game in this regard. Unlike monolithic DAO implementations, modular DAO implementations allow for quick testing and iterations, which ultimately allow organizations to evolve quickly and efficiently. Often when we think about flexibility in systems design, it comes with trade-offs â€“ typically around things like security. But flexibility doesnâ€™t necessarily require sacrificing security. Using tools like [pods](https://www.orcaprotocol.org/), DAOs can build modular systems, which maintain security at the local pod level, while enabling flexibility at the DAO level. # Becoming Evolutionary So you want to build an evolutionary organization, anon? **Start simple.** Stop trying to design the most sophisticated governance system. Start with something simple and evolve from there. **Fail intentionally.** Make assumptions. Test those assumptions. Repeat. **Build modular.** Think about your organization as a car. You can swap out parts and itâ€™ll still run just fine.


Pod-pilled? Ready to go modular? Well youâ€™re in luck â€“ weâ€™ve got some big announcements coming up. [Follow us on Twitter](https://twitter.com/OrcaProtocol) to stay updated on all things pods.

body:
Shen Mo Chen is busy in the kitchen, lampblack machine hum softly, the air is overflowing with the aroma of food.

Yan Caiyu leans on the kitchen door from beginning to end, while squeezing the bottle and the remaining yoghurt residue fight, while watching Shen Mo Chen cook.

title: Designing a task creation flow for a task manager
body:
## Intro

Delightree is a SAAS company which focus was to automate Standard Operation Procedures) SOP for franchises - they have pivoted since I left the company.

I joined the company when they had just got funding based on an MVP, and my task was to re-design the interface to make it a sellable product.

![Home: before & after](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4Scd8o1WnLcTp-hKk7r5h.png?height=900&width=1600)

One of the hypothesis the product manager wanted to validate was that tasks would be created by store managers, which were part of the Deskless Workforce. Hence, they needed a way to create a task for their team.

## Discovery

As part of the discovery process we had client interviews and input from the Customer Success team. Based on it, we created a list of requirements we needed to fulfill when creating a task:

1. A title for the task
2. A description for the task
3. Any attachments that were relevant for the assignee to complete the task
4. There were 2 modes
   1. Simple task
   2. Task with To-dos
5. Had to be scheduled for a specific day
   1. Could have a specific completion time
   2. Could be a one time task
   3. Could be a repetitive task
      1. Repetitive tasks had a set of different variations
6. Had to be assigned to different people
   1. Could be assigned to individuals
   2. Could be assigned to the whole store

![Initial design for the task creation flow](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_6YXJqNlndKYV5hvyBJro.png?height=900&width=1600)

## Decisions

As it was a lot of information, we decided to break the creation into a step by step flow that reduced the cognitive noise and help them focus on the task at hand. It ended up being divided into a 4 section flow.

![Step by step process for the task creation flow](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LrZhTccgYeAMLUunI7bDw.png?height=900&width=1600)

### Details

The details section grouped everything that was related with the information the Assignee needed to know in order to be able to complete the task:

* Title
* Description
* Attachments

![Task details](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/o0u6bmedomK1yPmTw0fVr.png?height=900&width=1600)

### To dos

During the validation process we realised there were 2 main type of tasks: The ones that were a simple confirmation task (Iâ€™ve made it), while other required more actions. The actions that we identified during our research were:

* Checklist (sub-tasks)
* Take a picture
* Attach a file
* Write something
* Multiple choice
* Rating

Based on this, the second part of the flow was focused on helping the user choose what type of task to create.

![Different options to select the type of to-do to add to the task (or not)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/uA6K8KC82sN8ojkLVF1mS.png?height=900&width=1620)

### Schedule

Also as part of our research and the data we had from the platform, we realised users created more repeating tasks than one time ones. Thatâ€™s why we made this the default option. Also, we added the â€œAdvanced settingsâ€ feature, which gave the users the flexibility to schedule their tasks with very complex settings while keeping it simple at first sight.

![Different options for scheduling a task](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/y8b40fy7ArOeGE_pQDxG4.png?height=900&width=1600)

### Assign

The last step of the flow was who to assign the task to. Users had the option to assign the task to a whole location where just 1 person from that location could complete it (Close the store, for example) and itâ€™d be completed for everyone who belong to that store, or to a specific individual. We referenced Whatsapp and Facebookâ€™s way of doing this in mobile, and mixed it with our specific needs.

![Different states for the task assign step](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/zITH2QQydiAZmlZoXJwm0.png?height=900&width=1600)

## Conclusion

![All steps of the process](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4TVUut97y-mHcVgEUV2f-.png?height=900&width=1620)

In the end, we came up with a flow that took users smoothly through the whole task creation process, assuring them they were doing that they wanted to do and guiding them all the time. This had a high rate of acceptance and rose task creation metrics, which made it a successful project.

title: The Token Compensation Paradox: Losing Reputation To Earn Money.
body:
***This piece was written in collaboration with [Eliot Couvat](https://twitter.com/CDTEliot) to expand upon the thoughts we shared on â€œ[De-Financializing SocialÂ Tokens](https://kairon.mirror.xyz/O_yvXUWh73LtfEJ3AdUQtZEPFK8dPp5Zmynf9qx-uYc)â€, we figured now more than ever would be the best time to get this conversation started in tokenized communities and DAOs. If youâ€™d like to check out Eliotâ€™s amazing writing on Social Tokens [make sure to follow him on Substack!](https://eliotc.substack.com/)***


---

Many people took the leap into Web3 and started contributing to DAOs because of the excitement of being paid in tokens.

Thatâ€™s because, unlike traditional salaries, tokens offered them almost unlimited upside (similar to equities), and contributors could earn a lot without bringing upfront capital.

But, continuing their journey and becoming increasingly involved in several projects, more contributors realized their tokens also provided them ownership, a voice over future strategic decisions, and unlocked new perks in specific communities.

And, after some time, many contributors found themselves stuck with their tokens, wanting to take profit, and make a living salary, but not at the expense of their voice and their reputation.

[https://twitter.com/samspurlin/status/1525613447240634371](https://twitter.com/samspurlin/status/1525613447240634371)

So how do we solve this Token Compensation Paradox thatâ€™s blocking DAOs and contributors from scaling and moving towards new horizons? Well, if we want to address the problem in-depth and re-think an entire compensation model used by thousands of DAOs, first we need to understand the underlying issues that come with the current situation.

## 1 - Beyond The Reputation Problem

The contributor compensation problem goes well beyond the simple struggle of sacrificing your reputation to make a livable salary.

With the compensation model we've built, we're heading toward wider inequalities within DAOs, more social pressure for contributors, and an ever increasing amount of DAOs failing due to this unsustainable model.

Indeed, if we want to pride ourselves in building new organizations, reinventing governance and political models; it's essential to separate voice from pay - otherwise, we're just building pure oligarchies and exacerbating inequality.

To illustrate how this model could eventually backfire on DAOs, hereâ€™s a real world example of what happens when you tie a personâ€™s bags with their political power: Sweden used a financially weighted voting system until 1910, the number of votes that one could have was proportional to their wealth. This resulted in a couple of individuals having more than half the votes in several dozen municipalities - almost like perfectly legal dictators.

[https://twitter.com/fkpxls/status/1531306137856909312](https://twitter.com/fkpxls/status/1531306137856909312)

For DAOs to [compete with traditional companies](https://eliotc.substack.com/p/working-for-a-dao-how-thousands-of), we should do away with the social pressure that comes with selling tokens. No contributor should have to "short" the DAO and go against their beliefs to pay the bills; nor should they harm or quit a community they believe in, simply because they can't afford to keep their tokens. And the problem goes even further; because the incentives are not aligned, the current compensation scenario can even make the most active contributors hurt the community, their regular sales negatively impacting the token's price and harming the decentralization potential of decision making. All of this, mind you, within the confines of the community they value most.

Your most fervent believers shouldnâ€™t be getting paid exclusively in the same type of virtual currency they use on a day to day basis to make decisions, grow their reputation, and push the DAO forward. By tying their payout to your DAOâ€™s native token, youâ€™re sacrificing the diversity of opinions you aim to nurture, and harming your project as a whole.

If we want to create new compensation models, we must rethink them from the ground up and align incentives between the DAO growth and contributors.

So how do we do that?

## 2 - Betting On The Long Term

Quite a few obvious ideas come to mind, and some have even been tested out. A handful of people argue that DAOs should pay salaries with Social tokens and use NFTs for reputation. Others have suggested paying contributors only in USDC, or creating two tokens, one for governance and the other as a source of liquidity.

While all those solutions seem promising, implementing or defining any of them as the de facto compensation model for DAOs would be missing the big picture.

Social tokens are much more liquid than NFTs, and allow communities to reward their contributors in a much more streamlined manner. They work particularly well as a reputation system and engage contributors towards exploring everything your community has to offer. Using them simply as a way to compensate contributors would simply kill their utility and their reason to exist. There's no such thing as an NFT that generates continuous engagement and rewards your daily contributors' loyalty.

As the Music NFT's artist [Xcelencia](https://twitter.com/Xcelencia) mentioned [in an interview](https://learn.trybonfire.xyz/case-studies-interviews/interview-with-xcelencia-equis-1) talking about the way he manages his community:

> *"I see social tokens as this continuous engagement. I treat it as a sort of loyalty or rewards program where I can keep everyone in and have them contribute in new and different ways.*
>
> *Whereas I see NFTs as these 'big moments' or highlights, the things you really want to commemorate like a great song, you want to put it out as an NFT. It's a different type of engagement."*

**Dissociating social tokens from reputation would kill your contributors' engagement, and so would paying them only in USDC.**

Paying contributors in USDC would mean firstly not sharing ownership (a core principle of DAOs), and secondly, forgetting that most DAOs usually don't have a financially liquid treasury beyond their tokens. Tokens are a great way to share "future" upside and recognize the effort of early contributors.

Paying contributors in USDC and providing governance tokens to decentralized decisions would surely solve the problem in the short term, but it would also end up nurturing a community without any values beyond the next paycheck.

**Something very similar would happen if you choose to create two tokens - one for salary and one for governance.**

While some may believe this solves the liquidity problem while retaining the "real" token's intrinsic value, what you're really doing is cutting your community's potential in half by distracting your message and limiting the true capabilities of tokenization.

Besides, the value offered by governance, access, and reputation can be incentive enough in some cases, just not in an everyday scenario for your average contributor. It's not unheard of to see social tokens being sold in "black markets" of sorts for non-negligible prices based on the value they offer alone. So, in the end, the 2nd token would need liquidity anyway, and the problem would still be the same.

All of those failed experiments showed us one thing. We have to see past our shared baggage of Web2 compensation models, where the main way to get compensated is to get a salary once a task is done. Web3 technologies are offering us new ways to share the value created while attributing the merit to the right people, and we must seize this opportunity to build better coordination models and organizations.

## 3 - Itâ€™s Time To Come Up With Revolutionary Ideas

Sure, *â€œWeâ€™rE So EarLyâ€* - and there might not be any clear-cut solutions to contributor compensation yet. But we are optimists, and there are so many experiments we could run.

What about exploring ways to fix this token compensation paradox from a protocol-side. There are so many Web3 native solutions and mechanics which would enable a more fair distribution of funds without compromising a social tokenâ€™s in-built utility, governance, or compliance with securitiesâ€™ laws. Think about mechanics such as staking, delegation of governance power based on merit, and emission curves. In DAOs with diversified treasuries, we could also envision contributors hand-picking their desired mix of stablecoins (or any token in the treasury) and the DAO token for compensation through customizable smart contracts. In the beginning, contributors would want more stability (90-10 mix), but as they entrench themselves in your community, the more they would tip the scales towards reputation (50-50).

Finally, another interesting solution has recently popped into the scene: tying your reputation to soul-bound tokens and on-chain credentials. While our platforms still have a long way to go in terms of security and actual use-cases for this type of tokens, the promise is there for a non-speculative asset that serves the only purpose of being your web3 ticket to access based on merit. By properly leveraging Soulbound Tokens and offering enough flexibility in their properties, communities could have the key to proper liquidity through their tokens, without compromising their contributorâ€™s reputation, or the DAOâ€™s treasury.

We can play around with the formulae for due recognition of work however we please, even involving systems that may or may not pay people **before** they complete a certain task based on their already accrued merit. We need only look at the chain, social tokens, NFTs, and all of the other tools we have at our disposal to make this process human-centric and token-enabled.

## Closing thoughts

We really are just scratching the surface in how we approach the future of work.

Web3 projects are very different beasts to your average Silicon Valley startup. In order to find a way to compensate the people making all of this happen, we could explore the seasonality of DAOs, our product cycles and monetization. Thereâ€™s so much to experiment with when it comes to peopleâ€™s relationship to impact, legacy and the future they want to see. Not everything needs to be a discord server and some Snapshot proposals.

***The answer to the token compensation paradox resides in keeping tokens in the equation while disconnecting them from financial value.***

If we want contributors to get credit for their work, and social tokens to reach their non-financial heights, we have to leverage the social tokensâ€™ true power and stop looking for use cases where they might not shine their brightest.

title: Designing a task creation flow for a task manager
body:
## Intro

Delightree is a SAAS company which focus was to automate Standard Operation Procedures) SOP for franchises - they have pivoted since I left the company.

I joined the company when they had just got funding based on an MVP, and my task was to re-design the interface to make it a sellable product.

![Home: before & after](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4Scd8o1WnLcTp-hKk7r5h.png?height=900&width=1600&size=medium)

One of the hypothesis the product manager wanted to validate was that tasks would be created by store managers, which were part of the Deskless Workforce. Hence, they needed a way to create a task for their team.

## Discovery

As part of the discovery process we had client interviews and input from the Customer Success team. Based on it, we created a list of requirements we needed to fulfill when creating a task:

1. A title for the task
2. A description for the task
3. Any attachments that were relevant for the assignee to complete the task
4. There were 2 modes
   1. Simple task
   2. Task with To-dos
5. Had to be scheduled for a specific day
   1. Could have a specific completion time
   2. Could be a one time task
   3. Could be a repetitive task
      1. Repetitive tasks had a set of different variations
6. Had to be assigned to different people
   1. Could be assigned to individuals
   2. Could be assigned to the whole store

![Initial design for the task creation flow](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_6YXJqNlndKYV5hvyBJro.png?height=900&width=1600&size=medium)

## Decisions

As it was a lot of information, we decided to break the creation into a step by step flow that reduced the cognitive noise and help them focus on the task at hand. It ended up being divided into a 4 section flow.

![Step by step process for the task creation flow](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LrZhTccgYeAMLUunI7bDw.png?height=900&width=1600&size=medium)

### Details

The details section grouped everything that was related with the information the Assignee needed to know in order to be able to complete the task:

* Title
* Description
* Attachments

![Task details](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/o0u6bmedomK1yPmTw0fVr.png?height=900&width=1600&size=medium)

### To dos

During the validation process we realised there were 2 main type of tasks: The ones that were a simple confirmation task (Iâ€™ve made it), while other required more actions. The actions that we identified during our research were:

* Checklist (sub-tasks)
* Take a picture
* Attach a file
* Write something
* Multiple choice
* Rating

Based on this, the second part of the flow was focused on helping the user choose what type of task to create.

![Different options to select the type of to-do to add to the task (or not)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/uA6K8KC82sN8ojkLVF1mS.png?height=900&width=1620&size=medium)

### Schedule

Also as part of our research and the data we had from the platform, we realised users created more repeating tasks than one time ones. Thatâ€™s why we made this the default option. Also, we added the â€œAdvanced settingsâ€ feature, which gave the users the flexibility to schedule their tasks with very complex settings while keeping it simple at first sight.

![Different options for scheduling a task](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/y8b40fy7ArOeGE_pQDxG4.png?height=900&width=1600&size=medium)

### Assign

The last step of the flow was who to assign the task to. Users had the option to assign the task to a whole location where just 1 person from that location could complete it (Close the store, for example) and itâ€™d be completed for everyone who belong to that store, or to a specific individual. We referenced Whatsapp and Facebookâ€™s way of doing this in mobile, and mixed it with our specific needs.

![Different states for the task assign step](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/zITH2QQydiAZmlZoXJwm0.png?height=900&width=1600&size=medium)

## Conclusion

![All steps of the process](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4TVUut97y-mHcVgEUV2f-.png?height=900&width=1620&size=medium)

In the end, we came up with a flow that took users smoothly through the whole task creation process, assuring them they were doing that they wanted to do and guiding them all the time. This had a high rate of acceptance and rose task creation metrics, which made it a successful project.

title: What Are Gamefied NFTs & Why Do They Matter In The Metaverse?
body:
**Introduction to the "meta:versesâ€**

The Metaverse according to me are interactive & immersive extensions of the Internet, that will be defined & differentiated by the "game:fied" mechanisms behind them. I prefer to call it meta:verses as I believe that, just like the "websites of the internet", "galaxies/planets of the universe", the metaverse is going to be based on 'verses' that will have different functions/mechanisms & use cases.

Gamefied NFTs: AKA â€œArtistic Arcade Metaversesâ€, a concept derived/coined by me as an indie game dev & an amateur generative artist which involves "crafting imaginary AI play into art pieces blended with interactive arcade inspired by classic retros or hyper-casual games that will be built & hosted alongside dynamic mechanisms on the blockchain" & just like single pages of the web, these are simple/single or non-fungible verses of the metaverse.

As the NFT community evolves: we see different forms of creations, scaling from 1/1 arts to PFPs, from music NFTs to photography & a lot more; but the concept of having NFTs as games might seem new but will be understandable by a lot of people if exposed & will help create a fun filled community as challenges could be created by individuals or teams as I call it; a league of "non-fungible gamers" & unlike casual NFTs, these will be multiple editions based or ERC1155 because they are meant to be played by 'people'.

The concept of gamefied NFTs is both exclusive & inclusive, as all games are hosted on multiple servers like IPFS or itch.io, and these will provide links alongside these crafts that makes it shareable by exclusive owners to non-owners to make it inclusive unlike other NFTs. With these, a lot of indie game devs will be able to hop into the NFT scene as a whole new community of creatives, presently we see a lot of passionate indie game devs running down the drain or struggling to be recognized, as they are not given actual opportunities to expose their cranky creations because big game studios are dominating the scene, but with decentralization & the rise of gamefied NFTs, they'd be able to create exclusive games for the community & with that keep the passion alive. And these way game lovers who would like to play or replay some of these classics are given an opportunity.

In the blockchain: These could also be used as a medium of token creation, using the $ASH ecosystem & mechanism as an example which Pak tagged "a token of creation through destruction" where art pieces released under the ecosystem can be directly burned & used to create new tokens which are directly distributed to the owners/burners as a reward unlike the actual burning system across blockchains. This I site as the second phase of my crafts that I tagged "Gamefied Fungibility & Interoperability" this is the part where all gamefied NFTs are merged & can be achieved by either creating an AI blockchain protocol or actual AI blockchain that will power these creations; For (1) Fungibility: Just like $ASH, thousands/millions of gamefied NFTs built by creative devs will be directly burned by owners after playing, as a decentralized means of mining new fungible/social tokens & in return acts as a reward for playing, more like a little 'Play2Earn' games. This will be valued & dynamically balanced by the AI system & by the community using it. This will also serve as a medium of â€˜burningâ€™ NFTs & earn an arcade game as a rewardâ€¦ For (2) Interoperability: With an AI system that has the ability to communicate with multi-chains, interoperable transactions will be carried out with a little fee, moving NFTs from one chain to the other will be made easy and will also trigger the minting of new gamefied NFTs to the wallet of the person who carries out this transaction.

In the actual immersive metaverse: gamefied NFTs will become gem-like collectible mini-games, having read/watched things like "ready player one" where we see many mini games coming into play as a form of quest or just a fun play & some actually involving the authors of the OASIS, we could state an example to say to access a certain weapon you must complete this mini game,

or just function as a sort of collectible to boast of like pokemon cards but played in a 2d virtual screen built within these 3d immersive worlds. We could have thousands of it placed across different part of "meta:verses" as actual arcade machines but will be more artistic as against the "retro times" where coins were inserted to play but here crypto(s) will be inserted to access these.

â€œThe metaverseâ€ just like I stated earlier wouldn't be just immersive worlds, as we are already seeing mechanisms that will be super importantÂ in the metaverse, why others are waiting for a single immersive 3D MMORPG as a metaverse, the mechanisms are being put into play, like Pak's "merge/mass" this I believe is an actual metaverse of mechanism that is "play/game" based. Then the metaverse/meta:verses will be gradually scaled to virtual worlds of fantasies, stories, or just fun based immersive extensions of the internet.

Let's build the metaverse bit by bit: "one verse at a time"!

title: What Are Gamefied NFTs & Why Do They Matter In The Metaverse?
body:
**Introduction to the "meta:versesâ€**

The Metaverse according to me are interactive & immersive extensions of the Internet, that will be defined & differentiated by the "game:fied" mechanisms behind them. I prefer to call it meta:verses as I believe that, just like the "websites of the internet", "galaxies/planets of the universe", the metaverse is going to be based on 'verses' that will have different functions/mechanisms & use cases.

Gamefied NFTs: AKA â€œArtistic Arcade Metaversesâ€, a concept derived/coined by me as an indie game dev & an amateur generative artist which involves "crafting imaginary AI play into art pieces blended with interactive arcade inspired by classic retros or hyper-casual games that will be built & hosted alongside dynamic mechanisms on the blockchain" & just like single pages of the web, these are simple/single or non-fungible verses of the metaverse.

As the NFT community evolves: we see different forms of creations, scaling from 1/1 arts to PFPs, from music NFTs to photography & a lot more; but the concept of having NFTs as games might seem new but will be understandable by a lot of people if exposed & will help create a fun filled community as challenges could be created by individuals or teams as I call it; a league of "non-fungible gamers" & unlike casual NFTs, these will be multiple editions based or ERC1155 because they are meant to be played by 'people'.

The concept of gamefied NFTs is both exclusive & inclusive, as all games are hosted on multiple servers like IPFS or itch.io, and these will provide links alongside these crafts that makes it shareable by exclusive owners to non-owners to make it inclusive unlike other NFTs. With these, a lot of indie game devs will be able to hop into the NFT scene as a whole new community of creatives, presently we see a lot of passionate indie game devs running down the drain or struggling to be recognized, as they are not given actual opportunities to expose their cranky creations because big game studios are dominating the scene, but with decentralization & the rise of gamefied NFTs, they'd be able to create exclusive games for the community & with that keep the passion alive. And these way game lovers who would like to play or replay some of these classics are given an opportunity.

In the blockchain: These could also be used as a medium of token creation, using the $ASH ecosystem & mechanism as an example which Pak tagged "a token of creation through destruction" where art pieces released under the ecosystem can be directly burned & used to create new tokens which are directly distributed to the owners/burners as a reward unlike the actual burning system across blockchains. This I site as the second phase of my crafts that I tagged "Gamefied Fungibility & Interoperability" this is the part where all gamefied NFTs are merged & can be achieved by either creating an AI blockchain protocol or actual AI blockchain that will power these creations; For (1) Fungibility: Just like $ASH, thousands/millions of gamefied NFTs built by creative devs will be directly burned by owners after playing, as a decentralized means of mining new fungible/social tokens & in return acts as a reward for playing, more like a little 'Play2Earn' games. This will be valued & dynamically balanced by the AI system & by the community using it. This will also serve as a medium of â€˜burningâ€™ NFTs & earn an arcade game as a rewardâ€¦ For (2) Interoperability: With an AI system that has the ability to communicate with multi-chains, interoperable transactions will be carried out with a little fee, moving NFTs from one chain to the other will be made easy and will also trigger the minting of new gamefied NFTs to the wallet of the person who carries out this transaction.

In the actual immersive metaverse: gamefied NFTs will become gem-like collectible mini-games, having read/watched things like "ready player one" where we see many mini games coming into play as a form of quest or just a fun play & some actually involving the authors of the OASIS, we could state an example to say to access a certain weapon you must complete this mini game,

or just function as a sort of collectible to boast of like pokemon cards but played in a 2d virtual screen built within these 3d immersive worlds. We could have thousands of it placed across different part of "meta:verses" as actual arcade machines but will be more artistic as against the "retro times" where coins were inserted to play but here crypto(s) will be inserted to access these.

â€œThe metaverseâ€ just like I stated earlier wouldn't be just immersive worlds, as we are already seeing mechanisms that will be super importantÂ in the metaverse, why others are waiting for a single immersive 3D MMORPG as a metaverse, the mechanisms are being put into play, like Pak's "merge/mass" this I believe is an actual metaverse of mechanism that is "play/game" based. Then the metaverse/meta:verses will be gradually scaled to virtual worlds of fantasies, stories, or just fun based immersive extensions of the internet.

Let's build the metaverse bit by bit: "one verse at a time"!

title: Canto Launch Sequence
body:
As the Canto launch approaches, the development team has prepared a timeline for the Canto community. The sequence will begin with Settlers of Canto, a dress rehearsal for the Canto launch, followed by protocol activations, and Cantoâ€™s inaugural liquidity mining program.

### July 16th, 11AM CT: Settlers of Canto

Starting at 11AM CT, we will open up our testnet for interested users to get early access to Canto.

For access, please head to [settlers.canto.io](http://settlers.canto.io/) and enter the necessary information. By Saturday at 11AM, you will have received test tokens in your wallet to use on the testnet. We appreciate your support. 
  
 **Update: The team is currently working on some issues that were identified on testnet. We'll announce an updated launch schedule when the issues have been addressed.**

### TBA: Pre-liquidity mining activations

**Canto GovShuttle** - A smart contract system for Layer-1 governance to enact its policy decisions in the execution layer.

**Bridging** - The bridge interface will go live. Users can deposit ETH, USDC, and USDT from mainnet via Gravity Bridge. ATOM transfers will be possible via IBC.

**Canto Decentralized Exchange** - A DEX with 0% LP fees for stable and volatile pairs, based on Solidly trading logic.

**Canto Lending Market** - A lending market for assets on Canto including LP tokens based on Compound V2 lending logic.

**NOTE and supporting smart contracts** - [NOTE is Cantoâ€™s unit of account token](https://mirror.xyz/0x4CeD9817cAD891aEFfbF5Fb7DcB6f3c6aEBd4228/DmiUSBdAED7ouIwvDZptFAM1XzpDNEKCF-GBuMDwWa8).

### TBA: LM Program Starts

At 11AM CT on July 20th, Cantoâ€™s liquidity mining program will kick off. To participate in the liquidity mining, head to [lp.canto.io](http://lp.canto.io/) and provide liquidity to the DEX.

**Canto will launch with 5 incentivized pools:**

* USDC/NOTE Concentrated Liquidity Pool (yx^3 + xy^3 = k)
* USDT/NOTE Concentrated Liquidity Pool (yx^3 + xy^3 = k)
* NOTE/CANTO Full Range Liquidity (xy = k)
* CANTO/ETH Full Range Liquidity (xy = k)
* CANTO/ATOM Full Range Liquidity (xy = k)

After receiving LP tokens, participants can earn rewards by supplying the LP tokens to the Canto Lending Market. Rewards will be distributed in the form of Canto dripped to the LP token suppliers.

**Canto is a high risk experiment that is testing a series of new ideas on the frontier of decentralized finance and social coordination. Please participate at your own discretion.**

### About Canto

Canto is a Layer-1 blockchain built to deliver on the promise of DeFi â€“ that through a post-traditional financial movement, new systems will be made accessible, transparent, decentralized, and free. Created by a loosely organized collective of chain-native builders, Canto is a new commons powered by Free Public Infrastructure.

title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Donâ€™t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: â€œI fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ERâ€. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, letâ€™s examine the reasons: (1) ainâ€™t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory to remember, nor the processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that â€˜youâ€™ exist is because your dadâ€™s sperm fertilized your momâ€™s egg. Somewhere along the way, â€˜youâ€™ came into existence. However, the answer to the question â€œWhy did you fall off your bike?â€ requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, letâ€™s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Letâ€™s begin at the moment in which â€œyouâ€ obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon accessing reality for the first time, â€œyouâ€ are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, become aware of â€œyourâ€ existence (â€˜consciousnessâ€™), as well as develop an awareness of â€˜thoughtsâ€™ and a procedure of thoughts (â€˜thinkingâ€™), achieve (some level of) control of your body and thinking (agency), and eventually learn from the environment (â€˜intelligenceâ€™, â€˜cognitionâ€™, or as I like to say, â€˜an ability to connect the dotsâ€™). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (â€˜informationâ€™) interpreted as truth (â€˜knowledgeâ€™), which we store in our â€˜memoryâ€™. The connections are a model that describes a functional i/o relation between bits (â€˜understandingâ€™). Putting this all together, â€œweâ€ exist as a conscious, intelligent agent of reality perceiving a sequence of moments (â€˜experienceâ€™) which we call life. It is almost as if reality is a Turing-Complete system (a BIG assumption) and our brains are a Turing Machine (another BIG assumption). The one thing missing in the Turing analogy is our â€˜imaginationâ€™ -- the power to â€œsee the unseenâ€. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. The brain (our â€œinterpretation engineâ€) is unique and not well understood. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now â€¦ but will definitely discuss it later.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about history is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration with them, and trust their experiences and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially events that we did not personally observe (and even when we do have an experience â€¦ our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are also complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, motivation, feelings, emotions, and biology) of which we may not be aware in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). Perspective is gained with an account of bias. The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- â€œtake nobodyâ€™s word for itâ€.

![A crude example of well-intentioned (perhaps) yet biased hearsay](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2dSC4WSKaPSXEgp5J1L9A.png?height=1945&width=2085)

A historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate itâ€™s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus of its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth â€¦ though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying â€œwisdom of the crowdâ€. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying â€œfatality of the mobâ€. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise\*\*\*, not truth-seeking. There is another common phrase, â€œhistory is written by the winnersâ€, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loserâ€™s side. This is not all the publisherâ€™s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but the missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias.

![Infinitism  -- The Ultimate Burden Of Proof -- aka The Absence of Evidence vs. Evidence of Absence Fallacy](http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive/phd070309s.gif)

Evidence is built through discovery -- a gain of information which improves our understanding of the circumstances which produced the evidence. It is still up to humans to deduce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Circumstantial evidence does not have the power to prove on its own. Rather, it can indicate the likelihood of a particular eventsâ€™ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other (and from that moment of history â€¦ not viewed as a â€œBayesianâ€ from the future) and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase â€œdrawing a conclusionâ€. Every piece of evidence or historical account has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and present-day graphical renderings do not prove dinosaursâ€™ existence. The evidence simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later â€œdiscoversâ€ them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil.

![The Gettier Problem (philosophy), GÃ¶delâ€™s Incompleteness Theorems (math), and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (science)Â all arrive at the same idea from different disciplines -- proof requires complete information and infinite precision. Conjecture is imminent (we settle for "beyond a reasonable doubt" in court.)](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/proof.png)

Evidence is an empirical starting point. It exists in context. A thorough assessment of evidence addresses as much context as possible. At the same time, there will always be missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that everything can be explained, so the world must be deterministic. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you donâ€™t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikantâ€™s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series with Brett Hall breaking down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that omniscience is not required to have â€˜creativityâ€™ -- an ability to create new â€œthingsâ€. You do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are **[First Principles](https://fs.blog/first-principles/#_ftn11)** -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> *â€œWhat I cannot create, I do not understandâ€*
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe the *Unseen*:

(1.) things that do not exist in the present moment and are of the past or future. For example, we can imagine hypotheticals.

(2.) things which are not apparent to the senses, thus not observable. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atomâ€™s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. Unobservable phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment.

An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely answers â€œHow?â€. An explanation is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, why something happened, or why something will happen, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root. Try the **5 Whyâ€™s method** to improve the accuracy of an explanation.

> *â€œScience is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.â€*
>
> â€” Carl Sagan

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Again, a partially true, incomplete explanation can be sufficient if we only care about a certain level of accuracy. An explanation is measured by its explanatory power -- the degree to which an explanation accomplishes an objective. The objective can be (and usually is) to accurately describe or predict reality. Explanations have degrees of completeness based on the amount of information present in them\*\*\*\*. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. A complete explanation leaves nothing to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and 100% accurate. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the â€˜justified true beliefâ€™ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is Truth (with a capital â€˜Tâ€™). This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as Truth (see [epistemic regress](https://www.informationphilosopher.com/knowledge/infinite_regress.html)). One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with Truth and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation accurately describes a fundamental Truth (a â€œlawâ€ of nature\*\*\*\*\*) because there is always a chance that we discover new information debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy and significance. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is simply an iterative assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *non-observables*, in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). There will always be unknowns and we do not know the significance of the unknowns. The highly significant non-observables are The Black Swans. We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retrospectively describe causation and also make reasonable predictions â†’ which builds information and iterates knowledge â†’ which inspires imagination â†’ which creates explanations. These â€˜creationsâ€™ bring a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to â€˜youâ€™). It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! Regardless of whether or not information is infinite\*\*\*\*\*\*, knowledge is not scarce. It is the product of intelligence and unbounded imagination and is stored in memory.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It is Truth. It just is\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. It is the purest form of objectivity (no interpretation necessary). Frankly, reality does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this realization is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we are an agent of change capable of effecting our own lives. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- uncertainty attributed to an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain â€¦ with one theoretical exception. The only proposed natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability of the probability distribution of subatomic particles in spacetime. This gets more interesting if you consider quantum randomness in a multiplicative series of moments. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an eventâ€™s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say â€œI am uncertainâ€, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the Truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing knowledge gaps (not to be confused with information gaps). Here are two ways to reduce knowledge gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- inducing a hypothesis from experience.

2\.) explanatory methods -- deducing a cause and effect relation from imagination.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem.

Empirical methods infer an independent factor (causal inference) from observations or experimental results (statistics). This is useful to identify information gaps. You can gain (uncover) information by changing the conditions (i.e. varying the independent variable to see the change in the dependent variable). Hereâ€™s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you may getting closer to a causal relationship (though there still may be â€˜Hiddenâ€™ variables\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* which are the actual root cause). However, correlation is not causation\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* â€¦. so â€¦ how do you know if the measured response in the â€˜effect variableâ€™ was the result of varying the â€˜cause variableâ€™ or if the independent factors are truly independent themselves? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Explanations describe â€˜the seenâ€™ in terms of â€˜the unseenâ€™ -- information not represented in the statistics -- and can implicate an unknown factor as the root cause. The reasoning offered in an explanation is based in â€˜possibilityâ€™ as opposed to â€˜probabilityâ€™ (though probability can also appear in an incomplete explanation). When something is deemed â€˜unexplainableâ€™, this indicates either a severe information gap or a lapse in imagination.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasiumâ€™s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire fundamental knowledge. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power. Lean on *First Principles* thinking or even better -- [Zeroth-Principles Thinking](https://medium.com/future-literacy/zeroth-principles-thinking-9376d0b7e7f5). After all, explanations are the best way to hunt the Truth. On the other hand, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information, and thus are exposed to uncertainty â€¦ so get used to it!

I glossed over the fact that â€œmeaningâ€ is an important part of the brainâ€™s interpretation engine. Sooo â€¦ what is meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? If we assume that reality is deterministic, then can meaning exist or can we have free will? Can there be a meaning of life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next postâ€¦

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding; rather, consciousness spontaneously â€œexistsâ€ without an agent or precise initial moment and is â€œyouâ€. I enjoyed Brett Hallâ€™s view of [ontology](https://www.bretthall.org/blog) --an explanation of being--what does it mean to exist. The model that I describe requires a definition for the concept of â€œyouâ€ (a whole exercise itself). I use a version of â€œyouâ€ that is a figment of the brain and represents an identity. â€œYouâ€ is awareness that exists as a state of consciousness. I also enjoyed Evan Conradâ€™s [article](https://evanjconrad.com/posts/how-to-feel-good) which offers a view that â€œyouâ€ are not your â€œthoughtsâ€ and suggests practical applications of this knowledge. â€œYouâ€ observe thoughts. At the same time, you have agency of thinking in the sense that you may be aware of a thought or feelings and its relation to â€œyouâ€ (as an identity that has control of an interpretation engine which does thinking procedures and serves the next thought). I would like to add that you are not your feelings. In Conradâ€™s view, both thoughts and feelings are real â€œtoâ€ you, rather than â€œareâ€ or â€œofâ€ you.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*Completeness is a function of access and precision. Explanations are incomplete when they are missing info. This is almost always the case when expressing explanations in spoken language because language itself is imprecise. A good question: can we know all information?

\*\*\*\*\* When describing physical reality, there is no such thing as a â€œlaw of natureâ€ or Truth (with a capital â€˜Tâ€™) since the description exists in the abstract realm of knowledge. There are just REALLY good explanations (called theories in science) that may resemble physical Truth because of their accuracy in describing and predicting phenomena, but we would never know for certain. However, there is a Truth. It exists and exists as reality. This implies the existence of False (with a capital â€˜Fâ€™). Knowledge is abstract thought -- an interpretation of information which exists relative to reality (Truth/False) -- and can actually be True or False when describing knowledge, but not reality.

\*\*\*\*\*\*The more important and deeper question is whether reality is continuous or discrete. This question is most famously illustrated via [Zenoâ€™s Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno%27s_paradoxes). Modern science does not even have a consensus on this answer. I think the answer requires a better understanding of time and information. Is information a property of reality? Does reality exist as a state of information at (that changes changes between?) moments of time? Can we create new â€œthingsâ€ (real or abstract)? Does the set of information (as elements) grow, accumulate, remain static, or simply change?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*I suppose the ultimate truth is whether reality itself exists or not.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is necessarily true, which requires a consideration of infinity. What happens when you consider time (the temporal relationship between cause and effect)? The most convincing concept of time that I can understand is that time represents a relation between moments of reality. In this concept, a moment is a state of information (reality) and time is the relation of moments -- The God Equation -- rather than the moment. Therefore, there are instances of information, rather than instances of time. Time describes change. It *is* change. If time is a relation mapping a state of info to another state of info, which [type](https://t-redactyl.io/blog/2021/03/types-of-functions-injective-surjective-and-bijective.html) of relation is it?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may address these concepts at some point. We perceive time as a sequence of moments (maybe a series when considering our memory), but time may not actually â€œbeâ€ an ordered sequence of moments. We do not have access to all of reality (information), which leads to gaps in information and knowledge (understanding). Also, knowledge lags information. The Truth Spectrum is not to be confused with true vs. false in logic. It is more closely related to the concept of [entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) in Information Theory.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* Any statistical model can attempt to predict reality. Some models are capable of making accurate predictions (though maybe not significant). Yet, any model trying to predict reality assumes a complete and closed system. We can use a model to make inferences about things not in the data, but non-observables belong to the realm of possibility (unknown unknowns), not probability (known unknowns). A change in the dependent variable (effect) may be caused by an unaccounted or unknown factor (cause) rather than the independent factor. This may be â€œconfounding'â€œ to some. Others say Hidden variables, once identified in an experiment, are â€œextraneousâ€ if they think they can be controlled. It is hard to control variables (especially unknown ones) in experiments, and physical experiments are temporal in nature.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Correlation is an association between sets, not a function. Causality is a function of sorts.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.
