title: Mips (MIPS.ST) Analysis
body:
*Iâ€™m not a professional and Iâ€™m not recommending anything. Just sharing my thoughts.*

**General:**

Mips is a company specializing on brainprotection for helmets. The company is world leading and started its research phase at 1996, had their first prototype ready 2000. Year 2015, over 1 million helmets had the mips technology implemented and 2017 they got listed on Nasdaq.

The technique purpose is to reduce rotational forces to the head and brain during impact by reducing friction between head and helmet. This is reducing the risk of brain tissue stretching that would normally lead to brain damages during impact. Mips got around 300 patents and the components production is outsourced to another company in Shenzhen, China (90%). This is associated with risk, but pretty much all helmet producer share the same geographical risk since most helmets are produced in this region. The helmets are easy to recognize in the stores, they all have a yellow sticker and the salesmans are well aware of the benefits of using this kind of helmet.

Mips have a total adressable market of 410 million helmets, with their newly entered market, safetyhelmets consists of 310 million helmets. The focus market as of know consists of 130 million helmets of wich they still only have a 10% market share!

![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F5ddc8d32-b912-4fa3-aa31-053e4115e2e8_808x828.png)

**Business model:**

Mips businessmodel is built on royalties from other helmet manifacturers. The helmets are in a price range with a minimum price of 150 SEK ($15) into 3 different segments, bycicle, sport and safety (industrial and law enforcement) helmets. Itâ€™s a cheap insurance that everyone should be having and I believe that if they would need to increase the prices, the company would not feel any negative effects from that. Those who already uses helmets will continue to do so regardless and in the other segments, motorcycle, riding, teamsport or industry there are laws forcing users to have helmets.

Recently Mips have benefited from law changes in 2020 when a test-standard for motorcycle helmet producers came through from Federacion indernationale motorcyclisme. The tests forces producers to do tests on rotational forces on impact. There have been discussions about implementing similar standards in other sports and practices too, but we will have to wait more for that.

Bike helmets have always been the main business. The safety helmets is a new segment that got added 2019 and still havenâ€™t had a big success. The reason seems to be the long process to get a contract with bigger manufacturers. However, in april 2022 they announced a collaboration with Uvex who is one of the biggest producers globally for safety equipment (revenues of â‚¬534M during fiscal year 20/21). How this will effect Mips is something we have to wait and see, but recent comments from Mips have been that they want to ramp up and reach bigger volumes in this segments some time during 2022.

In november they launched a virtual testlab that lets helm designers test their models on a computer before doing it physically. This means that a test-simulation only takes 10 days to complete instead of the previous 50 days. Totally there have been 50Â 000 tests (according to the news report 2021).

Mips have through the years been competitive. Year 2021, 12 million helmets with Mips tech got sold, the year before it was 7,2million. Third-part tests have been done. Mips bike helmets are considerably better than the competitors, in the top 10, 9 of the helmets using Mips. Top 10 in snowboarding have 5.

Full list: <https://helmet.beam.vt.edu/bicycle-helmet-ratings.html>

There are a few competitors but they are small and limited. They promise more than they can provide as of know. Last time I heard about a bigger threat was when Trek and Bontragers new helmets 2019 was provided with a newly made material called WaveCel that was supposed to be 48x better than a traditional helmet and 3-12x better than Mips. WaveCels tests was then proved to be insufficient. HÃ¶vding is another competitor but they have an airbag solution but itâ€™s not really popular, either itâ€™s because itâ€™s not convenient, the price of 300â‚¬ is to much or because people donâ€™t trust that kind of technology yet. It also needs to be charged to use (alot of people seem to have battery problems too), you also need to put it in idle to not activate when not being on the bike. According to insurance company Folksam, itâ€™s not a helmet to trust. 2020 It got a â€œtrustedâ€-grade by Folksam but have since then been removed (while all Mips helmet tested got a good grade).

Competition is not on the same lever yet.

Another competitor entering the research phase is public swedish company Autoliv (7 billion SEK market cap, making safetysystems for cars) together with helmet manufacturer POC to make a helmet with a airbag solution also. However, this one is going to try to apply Mips businessmodel instead of HÃ¶vdings and as mentioned is just in the research state.

**Financials**

The debt of the company is non-existent. Â They can really decide to pay of their debts whenever they want. They have a cash account of 98M SEK and total debts of 106M. They are not capital intensive either. The operating cash flow the last 2 years have been 277M SEK (116M SEK) with cash flow in investing staying at low -11M SEK (-15M SEK) that contributes to a strong free cash flow. Top-line CAGR is at 27% between 2016-2021. Gross margins at around 75% and G&A and R&D to sales getting lower and lower for every year. EBIT margin 2021 was at 53% with a net margin of 41%. Q1 2022 have also shown strong sales with a revenue growth of 65%.

![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fd94b6654-34e4-49c4-a79a-b72857120af3_576x246.png)

Also, notice the ROIC the last years. Worth mentioning that Mips had problems growing during corona mainly due to lack of components at the helmet factories. There is a big order backlog with accounts receivables to sales beeing at 1,24 wich is very high considering that they have been between 0,25 to 0,35 the last 5 years.

title: Freetrailers (FREETR) analysis
body:
*Iâ€™m not a professional and Iâ€™m not recommending anything. Just sharing my thoughts.*

## **General:**

Winner of danish e-commerce award 2022 for companies with revenues below 100M DKK. Freetrailers business is lending trailers and now more recently e-bikes (with big baskets for goods transportation) in Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Germany through an app to unlock a bluetooth lock either for free or very cheap. Their model is to rent their service to a partner that have access to a big parking, Freetrailers put the other companies logo on the trailer (that way the other company can market themselves) and is also doing the maintenance of all the trailers. The contracts are usually around 3-4 years. They are also making money from the consumers using the trailers, but more of that later.

Alof of big companies are currently using Freetrailers services, IKEA is a long-term customer. Others worth mentioning is ICA (biggest grocery store in Sweden), COOP (2nd biggest grocery chain), Elgiganten (popular technology store), REMA 1000 (big grocery store in Norway+Denmark), Europris (biggest grocery store in Norway. Alot of other big hardware/bulding material stores such as Byggmax, Beijer, Woody, and XL Bygg are also connected. Having Freetrailer have become a way to attract customers. However, the users of the trailer DO NOT need to shop at the retailer where they are renting the trailer.

The utilization rate for the trailers is up to 89% (Denmark 90%, Sweden 97%, Norway 69% and Germany 20%). However, the utilization rate is calculated by number of bookings divided by days (you rent the trailer until the store opens the next day, most people do give it back much earlier though). What I can see myself in the app, they are less popular during the working days, but every trailer is used several times a day in the weekends, this is what is boosting the number.

**The app:**

The app have over 100Â 000 downloads on Google play with 10Â 000 reviews and an average score of 4.8 out of 5 stars. There is a big flow of positive comments, the few ones that are giving 1 star is due to technical issues (such as the trailer not opening for different reasons). Those commenters are being contacted by freetrailers support. The app made keeping track of unused trailers easier and have also made is possible for people to lend it when the store is closed.

\*\*Consumers: \*\*Â The biggest share of the revenue comes from the consumers (70%), partners account for 20% and other is 10%. You donâ€™t actually need to pay for using the trailer, but on the weekend, they are so popular that making the reservation fee of 29SEK and with (49SEK) or without (0SEK) Â insurance is worth it (without insurance you will have to pay somewhere between 150SEK (broken or lost adapter) to 4500 SEK (stolen trailer) based on damage/delayed return etc. Like I mentioned before, itâ€™s possible to lend the trailer until before the store opens the next day. However, most people turn it in the same day the rent it. Adding on extra time cost 199 SEK per day.

![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F1c7c0734-d3a9-4fcc-bd65-d677aae021e9_649x121.png)

Going forward, the current targeting market is approximately 70Â 000 trailers.

![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F54ecff8c-7dcd-4441-b978-a49add20b564_672x229.png)

**Competitors:**

Competitors is old traditional gas stations where the price of lending varies between 150-350SEK for 0-3 hours. Other competitors are the local renters, but they match the prices of the gas stations. The biggest difference is the technologic solution, where the competitors are using a old outdated model. Another difference is that Freetrailers have the same price for all different kind of sizes, while itâ€™s even more expensive somewhere else. In short, not only does Freetrailers have pricing power (being more than half the price the have potential to increase the prices, without hurting the consumers wallet), the app means a more effective operation, getting useful data on consumer usage and the luxury of lending when some stores are still closed ( 253 working days and 112 weekends)

They have a first mover advantage in northern Europe, there is also a company in Poland and USA being new potential markets to expand too. That is not communicated yet though, but during IPO there was a plan to enter Finland and Benelux. Programming software to hardware is not an easy task either, and I have not heard about any other company doing the same thing. During corona there have even been a problem meeting the demand due to component issue.

## **Financials:**

For many years have they lost money on their business, but since 2 years ago they have passed their breakeven point and since then they have been able to scale up in a much faster pace. Revenue growth have the last 3 years been betwwen 15-28% Â (19,8% CAGR), gross margins just above 40%. G&A to revenue have gone down significantly. Net margins at fiscal year 2019/2020 at 2%, and 8,5% at 2020/2021. Currently, the 3 quarters in 2021/2022, the net margin is sitting at 12%. Showing proof of the scalability strength. ROIC also on positive numbers, 15% last year and 5% year before that, free cash flow also on positive last 2 years.

![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fd211d8fc-becf-40d4-9c51-2244e9c30d21_654x222.png)

Rented trailers per month, year 2018-2020

![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F2fc0fe48-d24b-4185-b55d-a93a5ca08183_817x545.png)

The trailers are not owned by freetrailers themselves, but are leased and then they put Freetrailers lock on them, meaning that they are not as capital intensive as they might seem, every trailer the past 2 years have accounted for roughly 20Â 000 DKK of revenue per year on average. Â Debt is not a problem either, debt to equity at 0,75. Cash & cash equivalents at 9,7M DKK and debts is low at around 5,5 DKK. EBITDA to debt at 1,36.

Freetrailers goal is to reach 1Â 600Â 000 rentals during 2025/2026, today they make an average of 80 DKK per rental, this would mean that they would reach 128M DKK in rental revenue.

## **Valutation:**

Freetrailers is already highly valued compared to itâ€™s financials today with a market cap of 320M DKK and P/E of 35. I value the business at 2025 to somewhere between 432-486M DKK, based on a total revenue of 150M DKK and net margins at 16-18% combined with a P/E of 18 (average in Denmark

1969-2003 and for Stockolm the last 100 years is 13, but take their reputation as a growth company into consideration). With a positive mindset that it can be better than that too.Stock price: 45-51 DKK

## **Catalyst:**

\- Revenue growth

\- Pricing power, increasing their prices for better margins and more growth

\- New type of trailers

\- Expansion to more countries.

The Saudis of 5,555 NFTs, whose artwork is a derivative in a 2D pixelated style similar to CryptoPunks. whitelist is 4500, public mint is 1000 free to mint on July 9. The collection has so far totaled 8.2K ETH in sales volume.

[https://opensea.io/collection/thesaudis](https://opensea.io/collection/thesaudis)

The Saudis is the latest hit NFT collection that comes just a month after another free-to-mint project Goblin Town made waves across the NFT market with its performance.

The rallying cry of The Saudis is MAX BIDDING, While the collection is off to a promising start, how it fares in the coming months remains to be seen. Nonetheless, this was â€œsuccessfulâ€ as a free mint.

Oil-price is a channel in The Saudis Discord that tracks the price of oil and is part of the communityâ€™s hope that rich Saudi oil tycoons will buy their NFT bags once they enter the world of Web3 at some point and want a pixelated cartoon profile picture as their brand.

The collection signals the top for oil prices, which have exploded in recent months, so can afford to drive the cars again.

The anonymous Rightblock set up a contract that minted nearly half of the public supply to hundreds of different wallets controlled by them. The contract then sent these NFTs back to their main wallet, from which they began listing.

Before The Saudis team had become aware of this, Rightblock made over $100,000 from selling the NFTs.

Freemint NFT launches seem to be working just fine as The Saudis lay the groundwork for future NFTs projects to adopt. However, regardless of how a project might be fundamentally unsound, there are always intangibles to consider. Viral marketing seems to thrive regardless of various market conditions in the short term but faces roadblocks to being sustainable in the long run.

People who are community jumpers, moving from one narrative to another, and maybe thatâ€™s how the NFT space operates right now, but probably not for long. set to innovate NFTs beyond expectations.

if the attention and hype are not backed by strong fundamentals and utility, the project fails. Marketing draws investors in, but it is the fundamentals that keep the project going.

title: One SMPL Trick
body:
9â€“5 metaverses and weekend metaverses, touch grass metaverses and [touch simulation](https://www.ft.com/content/4be5677b-bc03-4e46-bbbb-68074e8dda6c) metaverses, living metaverses and dying metaverses. With a hypnotic timbre, Mark Zuckerberg tells a story about the world to come that says everything there will be just as it is here. Just as our room is now, so it will be in the world to come; where our baby sleeps now, there too it will sleep in the other world. And the clothes we wear in this world, those too we will wear there. Everything will be as it is now, just differently textured.

The familiarity of variable-poly surfaces, however, belies the novel forms of visuality that animate the metaverse. Beneath the illusory layer of avatars and environments, techniques such as subtle gaze direction exploit research on human visual cognition and attention, while computer vision algorithms are refined by data synthesized using computer graphics. For humans, these new images operate below the threshold of perception; for machines, they provide the foundation of perception. Machine learning models trained on synthetic data, which is diverse and perfectly labeled by design, generalize better than models trained on real data, enabling avatars to represent users in granular detail. The development of immersive technologies constitutes its own form of vision.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Z0PeTXBZUBO9hyIKVK9T3.jpeg?height=883&width=1365&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

SMPLverse NFTs use facial recognition to retrieve [data synthesized by Microsoft to train face tracking algorithms for its mixed reality headsets](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2109.15102.pdf). Like many pfp projects, the Microsoft dataset uses procedural generation to randomly create and render faces without any manual intervention. The images combine a generative 3D face model with a library of artist-created assetsâ€”including textures, hair, and clothingâ€”and SMPL, a body mesh used to animate avatars in virtual environments. Though the synthetic images are indifferent to human vision, they tempt an overidentification: their verisimilitude is formally irrelevant to machine learning, yet it remains the only method of achieving functional equivalence with real data.

After minting, you receive a token with which you can submit an image through a webcam interface. Your submitted image is written to the token as a hash and matched to the next-closest smpl using a facial recognition model. Whereas the matched image mimics the form of your identity, the hash stored in the token preserves its content, although indecipherably (the image is hashed using a one-way compression function). When the image is matched, it receives one attribute: confidence. Confidence assesses the likelihood that your image matches the smpl you receive. Confidence is a declining measure: as more smpls are matched, your likelihood of receiving a high confidence match decreases.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Ua2pugKf_c16nk4xt8MhA.png?height=512&width=1024&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

Visually, the training images suggest identity play, emulating the avatars whose naturalism they are meant to enhance. Their effect, however, is to attune algorithms ever more precisely to usersâ€™ physical selves: the dataset expresses how users appear to virtual environments as much as how they appear in them. The minting process elaborates this tension between individual agency and computational constraint, voluntarism and determinism. Even a pool of 100,000 images is too small to consistently produce high confidence matches.

Unlike the elective avatars that crowd the metaverseâ€™s surface, SMPLverse NFTs are avatars for the metaverseâ€™s infrastructure. Beyond digital cultureâ€™s native identity paradigmâ€”[whereby identity is constructed and maintained strategically, as if from a third person perspective](https://gilbert.mirror.xyz/T_tVYHzaibzJ36fdkrBz-lF0hAcuL8l9F5bswPeO4lg)â€”SMPLverse maps the nonhuman identities conceived by machine learning. Though the secondary market may stage the traumatic return of the elective avatar repressed by the userâ€™s biometric identity, it cannot mask the fact that the synthetic images are themselves proxies for seeing machines, which exceed and overcome the human binary of pseudonymity and identity.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/65U1_J5nnhymnckIKe9lu.jpeg?height=288&width=249)

SMPLverse can be minted at [smplverse.xyz](https://smplverse.xyz/). More details can be found on our [Twitter](https://twitter.com/smplverse) and our [Discord](https://discord.gg/2hWDykfUdq).

title: Experience Autonomyâ€™s Self-Transferring NFTs with MetaDungeon!
body:
**This past weekend, we were thrilled to announce our forthcoming NFT-powered game, MetaDungeon, at this yearâ€™s Metaverse Summit event in Paris!**

## Worldâ€™s first player vs. blockchain and aNFTs

[MetaDungeon](http://meta-dungeon.io) is the first NFT-powered game that inverts the classic player versus environment (PvE) genre, and introduces a new concept of [player versus blockchain](https://mirror.xyz/0x6B87AbC02Fc4E2406219C69ecE0280ca39476b31/flj3TLtY-0mtkuwHj46Cr-7bEf6JuCV85zT-Ok09kSY) (PvB) â€“ where players are able to engage and fight with Web3 objects, such as NFTs and on-chain characters. This project is the first time a decentralized automation protocol for NFTs and blockchain games has been deployed.Â 

The game integrates multiple automation features to achieve [autonomous NFTs (aNFTs)](https://mirror.xyz/0x6B87AbC02Fc4E2406219C69ecE0280ca39476b31/6wGjQ-Saz4YUISqx3oXS1tQXLLOdXaC_WfFYKlqoq-Y), and for the first time, on-chain non-playable characters (NPCs). aNFTs are an iteration of NFTs that have the ability to vote, fund, and even transfer themselves thanks to the automation capabilities of the Autonomy protocol. MetaDungeon is also the first blockchain game that requires players to be collaborative and rely on team mechanics, incorporating other NFT projects which players own as an essential part of gameplay.

"The vast majority of characters in Web2 games like Cyberpunk 2077 or World of Warcraft are NPCs that interact with each other or the player independently,â€ says James Key, Founder and CEO of Autonomy. â€œThrough the development of aNFTs, it is now possible to build these types of engaging characters a blockchains. This represents a watershed moment for blockchain gaming and metaverses to build the types of games that generations of gamers are familiar with, and vastly expand the variety of games that can be built on blockchains."

## How to participate in MetaDungeon

The MetaDungeon game consists of Heroes and Bosses, where all Bosses are aNFTs and each player is a Hero NFT. Heroes team up to fight world Bosses (aNFTs) and score loot worth real money. Players interact with 3 sets of NFTs: Heroes, the players in the game; Bosses, who the Heroes fight; and Gear, the unique items that Bosses drop. Players have the opportunity to earn loot from killing each Boss in the form of NFTs and tokens, which a Boss holds. Holding a Player NFT and defeating a boss is all thatâ€™s needed to receive loot. For a full breakdown of the game, visit the [Autonomy Blog](https://blog.autonomynetwork.io/enter-the-metadungeon-38485dc12559).

Players will be able to obtain a Hero NFT via the Genesis Drop, which will happen in three phases.Â 

* Phase one: Sign up for the [mintlist form](https://form.typeform.com/to/u2RioRYq?typeform-source=blog.autonomynetwork.io) to secure guaranteed access to mint at least one Hero on August 9, 2022.
* Phase two: Allowlisted communities (who already hold certain yet-to-be-revealed NFTs) will have a chance to mint an NFT on August 10, 2022, on a first come first serve basis.Â 
* Phase three: There will be a Hero NFT public sale on August 11, 2022, during which anyone will be able to get their hands on the remaining collection of Hero NFTs â€“ if there are any left standing.

title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Donâ€™t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: â€œI fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ERâ€. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, letâ€™s examine the reasons: (1) ainâ€™t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory to remember, nor the processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that â€˜youâ€™ exist is because your dadâ€™s sperm fertilized your momâ€™s egg. Somewhere along the way, â€˜youâ€™ came into existence. However, the answer to the question â€œWhy did you fall off your bike?â€ requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, letâ€™s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Letâ€™s begin at the moment in which â€œyouâ€ obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon accessing reality for the first time, â€œyouâ€ are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, become aware of â€œyourâ€ existence (â€˜consciousnessâ€™), as well as develop an awareness of â€˜thoughtsâ€™ and a procedure of thoughts (â€˜thinkingâ€™), achieve (some level of) control of your body and thinking (agency), and eventually learn from the environment (â€˜intelligenceâ€™, â€˜cognitionâ€™, or as I like to say, â€˜an ability to connect the dotsâ€™). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (â€˜informationâ€™) interpreted as truth (â€˜knowledgeâ€™), which we store in our â€˜memoryâ€™. The connections are a model that describes a functional i/o relation between bits (â€˜understandingâ€™). Putting this all together, â€œweâ€ exist as a conscious, intelligent agent of reality perceiving a sequence of moments (â€˜experienceâ€™) which we call life. It is almost as if reality is a Turing-Complete system (a BIG assumption) and our brains are a Turing Machine (another BIG assumption). The one thing missing in the Turing analogy is our â€˜imaginationâ€™ -- the power to â€œsee the unseenâ€. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. The brain (our â€œinterpretation engineâ€) is unique and not well understood. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now â€¦ but will definitely discuss it later.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about history is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration with them, and trust their experiences and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially events that we did not personally observe (and even when we do have an experience â€¦ our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are also complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, motivation, feelings, emotions, and biology) of which we may not be aware in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). Perspective is gained with an account of bias. The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- â€œtake nobodyâ€™s word for itâ€.

![A crude example of well-intentioned (perhaps) yet biased hearsay](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2dSC4WSKaPSXEgp5J1L9A.png?height=1945&width=2085)

A historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate itâ€™s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus of its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth â€¦ though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying â€œwisdom of the crowdâ€. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying â€œfatality of the mobâ€. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise\*\*\*, not truth-seeking. There is another common phrase, â€œhistory is written by the winnersâ€, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loserâ€™s side. This is not all the publisherâ€™s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but the missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias.

![Infinitism  -- The Ultimate Burden Of Proof -- aka The Absence of Evidence vs. Evidence of Absence Fallacy](http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive/phd070309s.gif)

Evidence is built through discovery -- a gain of information which improves our understanding of the circumstances which produced the evidence. It is still up to humans to deduce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Circumstantial evidence does not have the power to prove on its own. Rather, it can indicate the likelihood of a particular eventsâ€™ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation entails observing each piece of evidence from that instance of history (not as a â€œBayesianâ€ viewing that moment of history from the future) and then imagining the logical sequence of events (and eventually using the power of hindsight) to form dependencies, hence the phrase â€œdrawing a conclusionâ€. Every historical account has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and present-day graphical renderings do not prove dinosaursâ€™ existence. The evidence simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later â€œdiscoversâ€ them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil.

![The Gettier Problem (philosophy), GÃ¶delâ€™s Incompleteness Theorems (math), and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (science)Â all arrive at the same idea from different disciplines -- proof requires complete information and infinite precision. Conjecture is imminent (we settle for "beyond a reasonable doubt" in court.)](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/proof.png)

Evidence is an empirical starting point. It exists in context. A thorough assessment of evidence addresses as much context as possible to understand its implication. At the same time, there will always be missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that everything can be explained, so the world must be deterministic. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you donâ€™t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikantâ€™s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series with Brett Hall breaking down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that omniscience is not required to have â€˜creativityâ€™ -- an ability to create new â€œthingsâ€. You do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are **[First Principles](https://fs.blog/first-principles/#_ftn11)** -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> *â€œWhat I cannot create, I do not understandâ€*
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe the *Unseen*:

(1.) things that do not exist in the present moment and are of the past or future. For example, we can imagine hypotheticals.

(2.) things which are not apparent to the senses, thus not observable. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atomâ€™s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. Unobservable phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment.

An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely answers â€œHow?â€. An explanation is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, why something happened, or why something will happen, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root. Try the **5 Whyâ€™s method** to improve the accuracy of an explanation.

> *â€œScience is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.â€*
>
> â€” Carl Sagan

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Again, a partially true, incomplete explanation can be sufficient if we only care about a certain level of accuracy. An explanation is measured by its explanatory power -- the degree to which an explanation accomplishes an objective. The objective can be (and usually is) to accurately describe or predict reality. Explanations have degrees of completeness based on the amount of information present in them\*\*\*\*. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. A complete explanation leaves nothing to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and 100% accurate. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the â€˜justified true beliefâ€™ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is Truth (with a capital â€˜Tâ€™). This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as Truth (see [epistemic regress](https://www.informationphilosopher.com/knowledge/infinite_regress.html)). One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with Truth and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation accurately describes a fundamental Truth (a â€œlawâ€ of nature\*\*\*\*\*) because there is always a chance that we discover new information debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy and significance. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is simply an iterative assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *non-observables*, in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). There will always be unknowns and we do not know the significance of the unknowns. The highly significant non-observables are The Black Swans. We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retrospectively describe causation and also make reasonable predictions â†’ which builds information and iterates knowledge â†’ which inspires imagination â†’ which creates explanations. These â€˜creationsâ€™ bring a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to â€˜youâ€™). It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! Regardless of whether or not information is infinite\*\*\*\*\*\*, knowledge is not scarce. It is the product of intelligence and unbounded imagination and is stored in memory.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It is Truth. It just is\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. It is the purest form of objectivity (no interpretation necessary). Frankly, reality does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this realization is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we are an agent of change capable of effecting our own lives. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- uncertainty attributed to an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain â€¦ with one theoretical exception. The only proposed natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability of the probability distribution of subatomic particles in spacetime. This gets more interesting if you consider quantum randomness in a multiplicative series of moments. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an eventâ€™s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say â€œI am uncertainâ€, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the Truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing knowledge gaps (not to be confused with information gaps). Here are two ways to reduce knowledge gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- inducing a hypothesis from experience.

2\.) explanatory methods -- deducing a cause and effect relation from imagination.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem.

Empirical methods infer an independent factor (causal inference) from observations or experimental results (statistics). This is useful to identify information gaps. You can gain (uncover) information by changing the conditions (i.e. varying the independent variable to see the change in the dependent variable). Hereâ€™s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you may getting closer to a causal relationship (though there still may be â€˜Hiddenâ€™ variables\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* which are the actual root cause). However, correlation is not causation\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* â€¦. so â€¦ how do you know if the measured response in the â€˜effect variableâ€™ was the result of varying the â€˜cause variableâ€™ or if the independent factors are truly independent themselves? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Explanations describe â€˜the seenâ€™ in terms of â€˜the unseenâ€™ -- information not represented in the statistics -- and can implicate an unknown factor as the root cause. The reasoning offered in an explanation is based in â€˜possibilityâ€™ as opposed to â€˜probabilityâ€™ (though probability can also appear in an incomplete explanation). When something is deemed â€˜unexplainableâ€™, this indicates either a severe information gap or a lapse in imagination.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasiumâ€™s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire fundamental knowledge. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power. Lean on *First Principles* thinking or even better -- [Zeroth-Principles Thinking](https://medium.com/future-literacy/zeroth-principles-thinking-9376d0b7e7f5). After all, explanations are the best way to hunt the Truth. On the other hand, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information, and thus are exposed to uncertainty â€¦ so get used to it!

I glossed over the fact that â€œmeaningâ€ is an important part of the brainâ€™s interpretation engine. Sooo â€¦ what is meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? If we assume that reality is deterministic, then can meaning exist or can we have free will? Can there be a meaning of life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next postâ€¦

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding; rather, consciousness spontaneously â€œexistsâ€ without an agent or precise initial moment and is â€œyouâ€. I enjoyed Brett Hallâ€™s view of [ontology](https://www.bretthall.org/blog) --an explanation of being--what does it mean to exist. The model that I describe requires a definition for the concept of â€œyouâ€ (a whole exercise itself). I use a version of â€œyouâ€ that is a figment of the brain and represents an identity. â€œYouâ€ is awareness that exists as a state of consciousness. I also enjoyed Evan Conradâ€™s [article](https://evanjconrad.com/posts/how-to-feel-good) which offers a view that â€œyouâ€ are not your â€œthoughtsâ€ and suggests practical applications of this knowledge. â€œYouâ€ observe thoughts. At the same time, you have agency of thinking in the sense that you may be aware of a thought or feelings and its relation to â€œyouâ€ (as an identity that has control of an interpretation engine which does thinking procedures and serves the next thought). I would like to add that you are not your feelings. In Conradâ€™s view, both thoughts and feelings are real â€œtoâ€ you, rather than â€œareâ€ or â€œofâ€ you.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*Completeness is a function of access and precision. Explanations are incomplete when they are missing info. This is almost always the case when expressing explanations in spoken language because language itself is imprecise. A good question: can we know all information?

\*\*\*\*\* When describing physical reality, there is no such thing as a â€œlaw of natureâ€ or Truth (with a capital â€˜Tâ€™) since the description exists in the abstract realm of knowledge. There are just REALLY good explanations (called theories in science) that may resemble physical Truth because of their accuracy in describing and predicting phenomena, but we would never know for certain. However, there is a Truth. It exists and exists as reality. This implies the existence of False (with a capital â€˜Fâ€™). Knowledge is abstract thought -- an interpretation of information which exists relative to reality (Truth/False) -- and can actually be True or False when describing knowledge, but not reality.

\*\*\*\*\*\*The more important and deeper question is whether reality is continuous or discrete. This question is most famously illustrated via [Zenoâ€™s Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno%27s_paradoxes). Modern science does not even have a consensus on this answer. I think the answer requires a better understanding of time and information. Is information a property of reality? Does reality exist as a state of information at (that changes changes between?) moments of time? Can we create new â€œthingsâ€ (real or abstract)? Does the set of information (as elements) grow, accumulate, remain static, or simply change?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*I suppose the ultimate truth is whether reality itself exists or not.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is necessarily true, which requires a consideration of infinity. What happens when you consider time (the temporal relationship between cause and effect)? The most convincing concept of time that I can understand is that time represents a relation between moments of reality. In this concept, a moment is a state of information (reality) and time is the relation of moments -- The God Equation -- rather than the moment. Therefore, there are instances of information, rather than instances of time. Time describes change. It *is* change. If time is a relation mapping a state of info to another state of info, which [type](https://t-redactyl.io/blog/2021/03/types-of-functions-injective-surjective-and-bijective.html) of relation is it?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may address these concepts at some point. We perceive time as a sequence of moments (maybe a series when considering our memory), but time may not actually â€œbeâ€ an ordered sequence of moments. We do not have access to all of reality (information), which leads to gaps in information and knowledge (understanding). Also, knowledge lags information. The Truth Spectrum is not to be confused with true vs. false in logic. It is more closely related to the concept of [entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) in Information Theory.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* Any statistical model can attempt to predict reality. Some models are capable of making accurate predictions (though maybe not significant). Yet, any model trying to predict reality assumes a complete and closed system. We can use a model to make inferences about things not in the data, but non-observables belong to the realm of possibility (unknown unknowns), not probability (known unknowns). A change in the dependent variable (effect) may be caused by an unaccounted or unknown factor (cause) rather than the independent factor. This may be â€œconfounding'â€œ to some. Others say Hidden variables, once identified in an experiment, are â€œextraneousâ€ if they think they can be controlled. It is hard to control variables (especially unknown ones) in experiments, and physical experiments are temporal in nature.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Correlation is an association between sets, not a function. Causality is a function of sorts.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

title: One of the 20%
body:
Yesterday morning, I was bright-eyed bushy-tailed; and prepared with a list of topics that I wanted to discuss for my weekly 1:1 with my manager. As I hopped on and landed on the waiting screen, I saw my manager and Devin on the call. I knew something was up but I joined with a smile. My smile immediately fell flat within seconds as I saw the distressed look on Devinâ€™s face. I knew he was going to deliver some hard news to me and he did.

[I became one of the 20% who was let go.](https://fortune.com/2022/07/14/opensea-nft-marketplace-layoff-crypto-winter/)  After the news, I was utterly dumbfounded and numbed, but I took the news lightly as I understood they had to do what was important for the business and the state of the market.  An hour later, I received the most thoughtful message from Alex and I burst into extreme tears; and memories of my time at OpenSea flashed before my eyes.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/BLhihGLpO3r03LC6Km3lS.png?height=381&width=505)

Waves of emotions filled my mind and my heart â€” from feeling appreciated, confused, sorrowful, angry, yet a bit relieved.

My journey at OpenSea is rooted quite deep and started with a hackathon back in February 2018. Alex, Devin, Dylan, Elena and a few others started a project called [Ethmoji](https://ethmoji.io/), where you can build your own Ethmoji and customize your own eyes, nose, mouth, and hair. The special thing about this project is that all the owners of each attribute used in the composition can earn royalties. This was the birth of PFP collections.

After this hackathon, Alex and Devin invited me to join OpenSea to build an eBay for digital assets as their founding designer. I declined as I was cautious of early-stage startups after being the founding designer at Zugata (acq by [Culture Amp](https://www.cultureamp.com/)). Also, I was really skeptical about the space and didnâ€™t quite understand why people were buying and [selling digital cats](https://www.cryptokitties.co/) online.

![Counter-clockwise: Jessica Phan, Alex Atallah, Devin Finzer, Dylan Field, and Elena Nadolinski. Photo taken by my beloved husband who has always supported every project.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5MkwMsGW7xq8gdOBVHfRx.jpg?height=960&width=720)

However, marketplaces are my bread and butter and Iâ€™ve always loved working with Alex, so I decided to work part-time with OpenSea. At the same time, I was off on my own venture â€” [traveling the world](http://jessica.is/a-hodophile/), consulting with other companies, while building my very own called [Hathorway](https://hathorway.com/).

In the Fall of 2020, Devin asked if I would be interested in joining full-time and leading Product and Design at OpenSea. It was such an exciting opportunity and a big role, but I had declined once again because I just created a new company with a friend after becoming a new mother, called [Ritual Meals](https://ritualmeals.com/) and I wanted to see this through.

Once 2021 rolled in, NFTs started blowing up and OpenSea raised their Series A of $23m, everything changed. And I realized the food industry is a cut-throat business, I left Ritual Meals and placed all my bets on OpenSea. Once I joined, I partnered really closely with [Nate Chastain](https://twitter.com/natechastain), who is one of my favorite people to work with despite the [insider trading fiasco](https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/former-employee-nft-marketplace-charged-first-ever-digital-asset-insider-trading-scheme). Together, we cranked and cranked features along with many talented engineers, and watched the bars in volume rise month to month.

During my time here, I had many first. I was the first 10 employees, the first designer, the first woman, and the first mother. I  designed the first several versions of [OpenSea.io](https://opensea.io/), [the blog](https://opensea.io/blog), [the logo](https://opensea.io/assets/ethereum/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/56143034414220578210570473379568418089845102446433003880655728973961440002049), [the first mobile app](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QKt59kExL-o),  [the first OpenSea and NFT explainer video](https://twitter.com/opensea/status/1446492795066372099) with [Thinkmojo](https://www.thinkmojo.com/), coined the phrase â€œthe world's first and largest NFT marketplaceâ€, and built out a killer design team, healthy design culture, and well-oiled process that I am proud of.

Yesterday was the end of this journey for me. In a way, it felt as if I have carried and given birth to a child, only to have it taken away from me. But I realized that OpenSea is not a child anymore, it has grown up and left the house. And itâ€™s time for me to let go and move on.

For the other 20% that were laid off, thank you for putting so much heart and soul into what you do â€” for building OpenSea for what it is today and laying out the foundations of the NFT space from the product, community, and team. Wipe those tears, brush any discouragement and doubts, and be so proud of what weâ€™ve accomplished together.

For those who remain at OpenSea, my only ask is â€œdonâ€™t fuck it upâ€ â€” for the sake of those that fall in 20%.  I know you will do an amazing job evolving it, so take good care with OpenSea. LFG.

And yes, once again, [jessica is unemployed](http://jessica.is/unemployed/). While Iâ€™m still deciding what my next venture will be, I will be taking a little break â€” perhaps [make some jewelry](https://hathorway.com/), [draw a little](http://jessica.is/animal-letters/), [write a little](https://www.fastcompany.com/3055836/how-feng-shui-could-help-build-better-products), and finally, be able to be present with family.

If you like to connect, you can reach me via twitter [@ohjphan](https://twitter.com/ohjphan)

title: Why I Chose to become a Whale Investor in Unstoppable Domains...
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4nUiONkwGpRSGRBaXaJBN.jpg?height=647&width=1024)

I have always considered myself a skeptical investor. Scratch thatâ€¦! I have always been a skeptic. This is because I find myself constantly weighing up my options in terms of logical premises, and lets be honest, sometimes, you just have to go with your gut! But even so, when I began surveying the basic principles that govern this new model of the internet aka â€œweb3â€, I found myself at loggerheads once more battling between the emotional highs of what others are doing, and what makes more sense!

Right now, thereâ€™s a plethora of information being posited into every available market and it can become quite overwhelming. So many people in the web3 space often DM me asking me how many NFTâ€™s I own (and we will get to this momentarily), and the majority of those conversations revolve around NFTs, -as in NFT art- yet this minuscule piece isnâ€™t about Punks or BAYC (Yup, Shoot me! Iâ€™m behaving like a like an NFT heretic).

### Of NFTs & NFT Domains

Whilst NFT art is definitely the conduit that created a real buzz around the world, most people within the space are completely oblivious to the fact that **NFT art is merely one block in an endless chain of possibilities with regards to non-fungible tokens**. Coming back to the common question that most NFT art holders lean with, it usually commences by the question, â€œ*So? How many NFTâ€™s do you own?â€* and my response is, â€œ*Over 1000*â€. This is usually met with a request of images as proof, or followed by the question of â€œ*Which collection?*â€ 

However, what majority of these inquisitors fail to realize is that **every domain from *Unstoppable Domains i*s an NFT** and the use-cases from â€˜owningâ€™ them are far too enticing to pass up that opportunity. 

Think about itâ€¦right now, even though you may be accessing this NFT article from a web2 browser, in time to come, there will be web3 decentralized sites set up that will give the member direct access, and as a corollary, phasing out the web2 sites. And in that inevitable case, it is not NFT art, or metaverse land that will become the most sought after commodity of web3, but NFT domains, without which, web3 will remain a pipe dream, because inasmuch as it will be constantly referred to, without NFT domains, the websites will still be web2-based, and that is a reality that web3 idealists will not support in the long term.

It is therefore, a highly sound deduction that NFT domains will â€˜directâ€™ the keyboards of every web3 enthusiast in time to come just as how .coms, .orgs etc. were the craze when the legacy internet was being set up. Those who have understood this, and have been piling up on the NFT domains will, in all probability -like their predecessors- come out as the overall winners in the space. 

However, there are some challenges when making the correct choice, and this is where my personal experience guided me, to what I believe, will be the next top CNS (crypto naming service) for web3., viz. *Unstoppable Domains*.

### The Tipping Points

When I first got into the space (mind you only in November 2021), I had engaged in an exhaustive deep dive juxtaposing the pros and cons and then revisiting some of the legacy domain policies. I was just swallowing up information like a vacuum cleaner on steroids.. And by the end of this feeding frenzy, my decision was based on the following *tipping points* that simply nudged me in the correct direction. They were;

a) Ownership

b) Cost

c) Immediate Utility

### To Own or Not to Own, This is the Question?

The web3 space is all about the â€˜*ownership economy*â€™ and it is indeed the fundamentally attractive point for both investors and the general populace. However, during my research into the web3 naming services, I found myself at a cul-de-sac of confusion as many of these naming services were still modelled on the previous web2 modus operandi regarding custodianship.

 For instance, *ENS Domains* is excelling in secondary sales, which is undoubtedly an attractive point when choosing where to invest, and a reason that causes one to become emotional when deciding, but the question of whether they are absolutely immutable in terms of â€˜ownershipâ€™ is a matter of great debate because like the legacy root before, domains are held in the custody of the registrar, and as a result, the owner risks loss of the domain by means of expiration date or failure to pay renewal fees. By this measure, ENS Domains did not meet the criteria -according to my understanding of the â€˜ownership economyâ€™-, and was a vital reason why I did not opt to invest in large amounts of .eth domains. 

*Unstoppable Domains* on the other hand, presented a more web3-ish option as the domains are stored in the custody of the purchaser to the point that even if UD wanted the domain back, they would require action from the purchaser to transfer it into their custody. The reason why this particular aspect was a tipping point in the direction of Unstoppable Domains was simply because, if I could not take custody of the NFT domain as my digital asset in my own wallet under my rules, then technically I never owned it at all, and if I never owned it at all, then it pretty much felt like a web2 version with some web3 face painting, and that was something that did not sit well with me. 

Now I am certain that the ENS maxis out there will disagree, and they are entitled to their opinions, but until I can be convinced of true ownership, knowing that if I went into a sudden coma, and awoke 10 years later, that my domain would not have been snatched away from me as a corollary of not being in my full custody, then that is a product I am not 100% sure of its claim to be within the â€˜ownership economyâ€™ -in my view anyway.

For instance, I currently own â€˜*whistleblowers.x*â€™ and in terms of the concept of secrecy and discretion in the very nature of whistleblowing, this can only work if it is decentralized and out of the crutches of those who wish to push their political agendas. Now, if I owned â€˜whistleblowers.ethâ€™ and established trust from various whistleblowers out there to freely communicate their information or crypto payments discreetlyâ€¦and if I missed the renewal date due to some unforeseen circumstance, then I could risk their safety as whistleblowers to disastrous effect. Thus, true ownership in this â€˜domainâ€™ is the factor that tipped me straight into the warm embrace of UD are they give me autonomy over the domain, and that my dear friends, is how I envisage web3. Donâ€™t you?

### Costing

Again, I found myself at loggerheads when ENS Domains kept coming up in my searches, and I was quite impressed that ENS does not have any price structure that causes you to spend hundreds of thousands on a domain. This is a bonus on anybodyâ€™s radar. What I did not know was that gas fees could be much more than the domain itself at times, and those who were much more experienced had been utilizing specialized tools to determine the best possible times when gas fees were low. I, on the other hand did not have that luxury, and found it a stumbling block that in addition to the initial gas fees, at every renewal process, I would be required to pay for gas. Some may argue that the gas fee issue is mitigated by purchasing the domain for 5 years as an example, but if I want to flip domains for quick cash then this option isnâ€™t ideal at all. Sure, it may suit those who have deep pockets, or those looking to HODL for the long term, but even then, if you hold 300 domains and each one requires renewal, there is a high probability of missing out on some of them -and .com users know all too well about that. 

With *Unstoppable Domains*, there is a once-off fee. You can get a domain for as little at $5 as a random pseudonymous wallet address, of even something like *jedigamer123.nft* for $5 (still available by the way) and never have to concern yourself with renewal fees, or expiration of the domainâ€¦ever! Once it is secured by your crypto wallet, you are the official â€˜ownerâ€™ of that NFT domain. 

The average price of the .nft is approximately $20, the .crypto around $40 and the .x is $100. The algorithm prices the more premium domains at a much higher rate and can range from anything between $20-$250k or more perhaps. When you are selling something completely, then you can understand the price hike for domains that are of higher demand. For instance, no sane person in the space would expect to pay $20 for â€˜business.cryptoâ€™ as that is a much sought after key word with endless possibilities. Incidentally, it belonged to @DiaryNoori (someone I can call my friend) and it sold on Opensea for $120k this year. 

In terms of cost, I prefer to pay for something once-off and know that it is mine to own, having never to concern myself thereafter with any kind of pricing that may jeopardize my domain in the case of any unforeseen circumstances or negligence on my part. This is my preference, and for those who are fine with having to continuously check their domains for expiration dates and to budget for that, then â€˜to each their ownâ€™, even if the incessantly laborious is what tickles your fancy. 

### Immediate Utility

Insofar as utility is concerned, we are still relatively early in the web3 space and whilst this is good, it does not mean that there shouldnâ€™t be immediate utility. There are a lot of naming services out there popping up like mushrooms after the rains, but many of them are just charging for domains that cannot be utilized at the base level for buying or selling crypto, let alone a market place to flip them. ENS and Unstoppable Domains are leading the way currently by providing utility in many ways, even at this early stage. The tipping point for me once again was the fact that Unstoppable Domains currently offers 10 extensions instead of one, so I could choose, -based on the name I was purchasing- whether or not a particular extension suited the ideals of that which was envisaged for the domain. For instance, if I wanted to have a domain with view to building an NFT project later on, I just couldnâ€™t see it with a .eth extension that could be self explanatory to anyone who saw the project. So was I to add \*\*\*\*nft.eth? Or just get a .nft? the latter was always going to make more sense.

Additionally, Unstoppable Domains prides itself in not just supplying names, but providing use-cases for the domains that will allow the holderâ€™s on-chain identity to travel with them wherever they travel in the world of web3. I will attempt to write a little piece later on regarding the utility of UDâ€™s NFT Domains, but for beginners struggling to make these decisions, I have found the variety at UD to be far more attractive, albeit unlike Handshake, that offers limitless TLDs, Unstoppable Domains has created a culmination of some of the most relevant extensions that are self-explanatory within the space and extensions that will become common lingo!

**Conclusion** - My choice to go all-in on Unstoppable Domains comes from a place that is predicated on logic because so many aspects about their mission  and product just makes sense in retrospect of the web3 vision that we all hope to see some day. Yes, many may assume this material to be biased, but as a holder of ENS domains and Handhsake domains too, my views are based on my experience. I believe that web3 is big enough for everyone to survive and I cannot see a future of web3 that does not include Unstoppable Domains as a leading naming service. With over 2.5 million registrations in the bag and hundreds of partnerships with crypto companies, Unstoppable Domains is going to be a force to be reckoned with, and I am proud to wear the badge of a UDwhale!

title: UBet Sports: Liquidity Provision.
body:
# What is it? How does it work?

Compared to traditionally centralized sports betting institutions, UBet is a fully **decentralized** platform. But what does that mean? One of the key differences lies in who is providing liquidity.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/YeuJPXDsps5YKIl_moRdu.png?height=1008&width=1542)

# What is liquidity?

When a bettor places a wager on a traditional sportsbook, they are *always* betting against the bookie, who provides enough liquidity to guarantee payoutâ€“if the call is good. In doing so, the bookie seizes all of the profits that can be made from transaction fees and bad calls. This is the foundation of the old adage: â€œThe house *always* wins.â€ The house always wins because the house provides all the liquidity in the traditional model of sports bettingâ€“not to mention their monopoly in setting the odds!

# Become the house.

As it is with the traditional model of sports betting, there are profits to be made through liquidity provision. But instead of forfeiting these profits by default to a centralized entity, UBet will allow anyone to become a liquidity provider to earn passive yields on their staked capital. â€œHow much?â€ you may ask. Liquidity providers will earn their fair portion of the reward pool consisting of bad wagers and a flat 2.5% transaction fee for all wagers excluding limit orders. In short, the more bettors there are, the more profit liquidity providers make.

# Bettor vs. LP Ecosystem

UBet will bring forth an interesting dynamic between the bettors and liquidity providers. While having more bettors will increase the overall size of the pie, having more liquidity providers will split the pie into smaller pieces. This will result in a self-balancing ecosystem between the bettors and liquidity providers because when the pie gets large enough, the returns will be very attractive to liquidity providers. But when there arenâ€™t enough bettors, liquidity providers may seek greener pastures for their USDC.

# What now?

The UBet Sports team has been hard at work and weâ€™re very excited to begin testing early versions of our platform. Get involved and get rewarded by signing up for the free **beta tournament [here](https://www.ubetsports.io/).** No purchase is necessary.

By participating in the beta tournament, you will help us validate UBetâ€™s cutting-edge financial technology and make sure that the platform is secure and functional for bettors and liquidity providers alike.

The beta tournament will be held every two weeks and you will begin each round with $250 in-game currency which you can use to place wagers on available games. The top 10 bettors by the end of the round will receive $100 USDC and the cycle begins anew. There is also a $10 USDC bounty for each significant bug reported so keep an eye out!

# The future.

In time, UBet will bring value to both bettors and liquidity providers to create a fair and decentralized betting economy as opposed to an unfair centralized oligopoly.

UBettors will enjoy:

* Better odds.
* Instant payout.
* Lower transaction fees.
* Unlimited bet sizes.
* And more.

UBetâ€™s liquidity providers will enjoy competitive yields on their staked USDC by leveraging the house edge for themselves.

At UBet Sports, we are super excited about the future of sports betting and decentralized finance. If you are excited as well, make sure to follow us on Twitter and say hello on our Discord. Weâ€™d love to hear from you!

title: Presenting the Revert Compoundor
body:
Weâ€™re excited about releasing a new feature today for Uniswap v3 Liquidity Providers: **fee auto-compounding.**

We think this will be useful for LPs depending on how long they plan to hold positions and what they expect their **Fee APR** to be going forward.

In Uniswap v3 compounding of fees does not occur automatically, as it does on its predecessor, and manual compounding of fees requires doing a few different contract interactions and calculations to:

1. Collect fees via the Uniswap NFT Manager contract.
2. Possibly check the amounts of token0 and token1 required to swap so as to maximize the amount of liquidity added to the position.
3. Possibly perform the required swap.
4. Add the tokens as liquidity to the position.

Additionally because fees do not grow at a constant rate, and the cost of compounding is a multiple of the gas price, to compound optimally requires constant monitoring of a position.

Because gas prices determine the cost of compounding, the deployment of Uniswap v3 on low gas price chains means that a much larger proportion of positions would be optimally compounded a much greater number of times that on mainnet.

To automate the above process we are releasing a simple protocol: Revert Compoundor.

Positions managed by the Compoundor contract can be auto-compounded by anyone. The ***autoCompound*** function takes any uncollected fees for a position, optionally swaps them to a determined ratio given the position range and the current pool price, and adds it as liquidity to the position.

A small fraction of the *collected-and-compounded* fees are paid to the protocol and to compensate the accounts call the auto-compound function for their gas costs incurred. This performance fee is set to 2% on launch and by design can only be decreased, never increased.

Additionally once a position is added to the Compoundor protocol contract, the position owner is able to conveniently execute the ***autoCompound*** function at any time, in which case there are no fees charged aside from the regular gas costs of executing the call.

We are publishing a draft of a [whitepaper](https://hackmd.io/@revert/BJcGIJQ35) that explains how the protocol works and how we are estimating the expected benefits of auto-compounding for any position.

Additionally the protocol contracts have had an open bug bounty on Immunefi since June 14th.

[https://github.com/revert-finance/compoundor](https://github.com/revert-finance/compoundor)

[https://immunefi.com/bounty/revert/](https://immunefi.com/bounty/revert/)

To give it a try just visit your positions dashboard, and for any v3 position you will see a â€œCompound Feesâ€ button at the bottom, by clicking on it a panel will expand that will show you the estimated benefits of auto-compounding your position given the current fee APRs.

![A hypothetical position that would benefit from auto-compounding](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RX4uGBzjUqUTnU-xEDLm1.png?height=1524&width=1098)

The total yearly improvement, and the time to break-even, will depend on each positionsâ€™ performance. Depending on each LPs strategy and expectations, auto-compounding might not be ideal. Particularly on high gas-price environments like Ethereum mainnet, auto-compounding should be attractive mostly to LPs with very high fee apr, or long expected time range on their positions.

We are also excited about launching this protocol/feature today simultaneously on [Mainnet](https://etherscan.io/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code), [Optimism](https://optimistic.etherscan.io/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code), [Arbitrum](https://arbiscan.io/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code), and [Polygon](https://polygonscan.com/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code).

So we hope you try it out, check if it makes sense for your current or future Uniswap v3 positions, and if you have any questions or comments, drop by our discord.

title: Presenting the Revert Compoundor
body:
Weâ€™re excited about releasing a new feature today for Uniswap v3 Liquidity Providers: **fee auto-compounding.**

We think this will be useful for LPs depending on how long they plan to hold positions and what they expect their **Fee APR** to be going forward.

In Uniswap v3 compounding of fees does not occur automatically, as it does on its predecessor, and manual compounding of fees requires doing a few different contract interactions and calculations to:

1. Collect fees via the Uniswap NFT Manager contract.
2. Possibly check the amounts of token0 and token1 required to swap so as to maximize the amount of liquidity added to the position.
3. Possibly perform the required swap.
4. Add the tokens as liquidity to the position.

Additionally because fees do not grow at a constant rate, and the cost of compounding is a multiple of the gas price, to compound optimally requires constant monitoring of a position.

Because gas prices determine the cost of compounding, the deployment of Uniswap v3 on low gas price chains means that a much larger proportion of positions would be optimally compounded a much greater number of times that on mainnet.

To automate the above process we are releasing a simple protocol: Revert Compoundor.

Positions managed by the Compoundor contract can be auto-compounded by anyone. The ***autoCompound*** function takes any uncollected fees for a position, optionally swaps them to a determined ratio given the position range and the current pool price, and adds it as liquidity to the position.

A small fraction of the *collected-and-compounded* fees are paid to the protocol and to compensate the accounts call the auto-compound function for their gas costs incurred. This performance fee is set to 2% on launch and by design can only be decreased, never increased.

Additionally once a position is added to the Compoundor protocol contract, the position owner is able to conveniently execute the ***autoCompound*** function at any time, in which case there are no fees charged aside from the regular gas costs of executing the call.

We are publishing a draft of a [whitepaper](https://hackmd.io/@revert/BJcGIJQ35) that explains how the protocol works and how we are estimating the expected benefits of auto-compounding for any position.

Additionally the protocol contracts have had an open bug bounty on Immunefi since June 14th.

[https://github.com/revert-finance/compoundor](https://github.com/revert-finance/compoundor)

[https://immunefi.com/bounty/revert/](https://immunefi.com/bounty/revert/)

To give it a try just visit your positions dashboard, and for any v3 position you will see a â€œCompound Feesâ€ button at the bottom, by clicking on it a panel will expand that will show you the estimated benefits of auto-compounding your position given the current fee APRs.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/D__XmTnOagS4ZCETk1gbN.png?height=3092&width=2196)

The total yearly improvement, and the time to break-even, will depend on each positionsâ€™ performance. Depending on each LPs strategy and expectations, auto-compounding might not be ideal. Particularly on high gas-price environments like Ethereum mainnet, auto-compounding should be attractive mostly to LPs with very high fee apr, or long expected time range on their positions.

We are also excited about launching this protocol/feature today simultaneously on [Mainnet](https://etherscan.io/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code), [Optimism](https://optimistic.etherscan.io/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code), [Arbitrum](https://arbiscan.io/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code), and [Polygon](https://polygonscan.com/address/0x5411894842e610c4d0f6ed4c232da689400f94a1#code).

So we hope you try it out, check if it makes sense for your current or future Uniswap v3 positions, and if you have any questions or comments, drop by our discord.
